content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												Mark of the Ninja is a side-scrolling 2D action game that can be played to varying degrees of stealth. As an xbox port, the game plays best with a controller, (it ought to be a requirement) so bear that in mind if you plan on purchasing it. That said, the game is completely worth the money as I can think of no other action game that does stealth so well.The game itself is not so difficult; it can be completed rather quickly if one wishes. The real gem in this game lies in the replayability; challenges and achievements that are fun and set to just the right level of difficulty. Multiple "costumes" (altered game mechanics) and a wide variety of skills/tools allow for a range of playstyles.Mechanics-wise, the Mark of the Ninja leaves nothing up to chance or question. Success is based on skill and everything about the environment is communicated to the player with visual cues. If the player character dies it is always the player's fault. No "bad rolls" or "cheese" here.While not a story driven game, the story in Mark of the Ninja does have merit for reasons I cannot explain without spoiling it. Just suffice to say that the player will do well to pay attention to the graphics.In short, I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2013
												I played late and have yet to tackle New Game+, but Mark of the Ninja has to be one of my top games of 2012.  It offers all of the stealthy exploration and interaction of the Batman Arkham series without the cruft.  The game is mission-based, but each mission allows backtracking and can be replayed later to find missing items, try out different tactics or aim for a higher score.  You can even take advantage of restarting from mid-mission checkpoints when failing to pull off whatever you intended.  Upgrades can be earned, but are not required.  While I tended to focus on takedowns and smoke bombs, there's plenty of room to experiment.  It's a giant, segmented playground and I love it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2013
												This has got to be the best stealth game I have ever played in my life, and is one of the best games I've played this year. A ridiculously well-done masterpiece, from start to finish. The stealth mechanics are amazing as this is the only game where sound, visibility and movement indicators are so well done. You always know if you will be spotted or not. Also, Mark of the Ninja has great variety, as you can complete each mission how you want it. Want to become a merciless killing machine, with upgraded armor and health regeneration? You got it! Want to become the living shadow, making almost no noise at all and flying through obstacles undetected? Check! Want to strike endless fear to your enemies, hanging both dead and alive while slaughtering terrorized foes like pigs? How about a no-killing policy, where you don't even have a sword? Check, check, check! A dozen of absolutely different gadgets also add to variety and make every playthrough unique. If you want, you can carefully lay down mines on the path and lure enemies with firecrackers, killing the guards remotely, or you can throw a hallucination dart and make the foes shoot each other down. Hell, you can even take a plain old cardboard box, hide inside it and just wait for the kill! Not only the playstyles and gadgets, but also the levels themselves add to the variety. If you see a heavily guarded corridor, you can always rush underground, trying to avoid various traps, but without the necessity of dealing with the guards, Or you can rush through the door, throw a smokebomb and massacre everyone. Of course, you might just climb on the roof, go through the ventilation chamber and lure off the enemies and murder them one by one. Or, you could just.... well, you get the idea. Each level can be beaten in so many ways it can be hard to count.Surprisingly, there's also a lot of diferent enemies. From your average short-sighted guard, who easily panicks to cybernetic assassins who detect your presence from afar to snipers who take you down in one shot. There's numerous types of guards, each of them must be dealt in a different way. The enemies also look really great, and so we come in to our second part of the game......the graphics. They are amazing. The levels look gorgeous in such a way, and as I mentioned, various stealth-related indicators look and fit here really well. Areas that you have no vision off have this black and white mist. Sound indicators have different shapes, sizes and colors depending on the strenght of the sound. Thus, you will always differ a footstep from a gong going off. Speaking of which, the sound in this game is great. It fits the atmosphere really well and the swish, swoosh of a stealth kill feels ever so satisfying. The music is great as well, it differs in both the tone and intensity if you are slowly climbing the walls or running away after you've been spotted.The controls are one of the best in a 2D sidescroller as they can get. The character will almost always do exactly what you want to, whether this could be hanging off a ledge without jumping off or doing a tricky jump off a cliff in order to land right behind a guard.  This makes even the hardest challenges force you to keep going or try a different aproach without any rage, as any deaths are because of your poor judgement and not bad controls.The challenges are incredible. Most puzzles in MotN will normally be solved in under a minute, but if that sounds too easy to you, and it should, there's always a sacred gong in every level. It offer a really hard challenge, based on the thematic of the level, forcing the most out of your problem solving, finger dexterity or ninja skill usage. The challenges are hard, and most of them will require more than five minutes each, but they are never unfair or unsolvable. There's so much I haven't talked about, like the great storyline, Mark Powers and many more things, but I think every single one of you should see for yourselves. Klei Entertainment did a really good job.Recomended to buy.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												A stealth masterpiece....!!!  :)I felt compelled to write a review; this game is quite simply, amazing. I was a huge fan of the first Tenchu: Stealth Assassin game on the PlayStation and this tweaks my nostalgia...I could not have asked for a better ninja game. Everything about this game screams terrific design. It captures the spirit of true ninjutsu: complete nothingness and silence, alongside the occasional assassination. The path you take as a ninja is completely up to you, ranging from a murderous nightmare towards every guard to an undetectable ghost. The game is more than happy to give you various options in approaching every situation. it totally reminded me of my old times platying Metal Gear Solid, trying to stay away from the guards and killing them when they weren't looking. If you enjoy stealth games, you'll have a lot of fun with this. It doesn't become repetitive at all and the art is beautiful to look at.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												I went into this game unsure of what to expect.  I've always loved Klei's art style, and while I utterly suck at Shank, I found its gameplay to be very tight and enjoyable.  However, I've had very little exeperience with stealth games and the hype for this was through the roof, which is usually setup for disappointment. I came out of my inital twenty hours with a new additoon to my favorite video games of all time.  Let me be the first to admit, this games narrative is probably its weakest aspect.  It attempts to emulate the kitschy ninja and martial arts movies of old, and while that's something I should love, I found the excectuion to be lacking.  A lot of the voice acting is pretty flat and there's a glaring thematic inconsisentcy to the gameplay's focus on true ninja techniques and the narrative's emphasis on the western misconception of "honor" among ninja.  However, that's easily overlooked thanks not only to the incredible job done with all other aesthetic qualities, but also the gameplay itself. This game is so ludicrously elegant.  So beautifully designed, fluid and engaging, that I almsot can't believe actual humans made it.  Humanity implies fallibility, and the core mechanics of this game have none that I can think of.  Every limitation is deliberate, every ability satisfying, every animation goregoud and fluid.  It all comes together to deliver on the game's central conciet: making you feel like a ninja.  Not an unstoppable badass with a hood and katana.  Not a one-man army that happens to dress like a feudal Japanese spy.  Not a barely-clothed cheesecake factory with a sharp fan who giggles and calls herself "kunoichi" while all the straight male gamers bend over backwards to call her a strong female character.  A NINJA.  An honest-to-god shadow warrior who strikes hard and vanishes into the night.  The core mechanics of this game and the vast majority of the way those mechanics are implemented are SUBLIME.  Unfortunately, there are some areas that are pretty "bleh."  In particular, the laser puzzles are fine when first introduced, but quickly become so tedious that I find myself ready to rip out all my hair at the roots and mash on the keyboard with my bloody disembodied scalp.  And there are some items that I pretty much never used due to how difficult it was to make proper use of them in the vast majority of situations.  But in the grand scheme of things, these are truly minor things, and all in all, this game is absolutely incredible.  I'd dare say it's a masterpiece.  One of ther finest blends of all the elements that make a game engaging and peerless in the way it presents a pop culture touchstone so often reduced to a generic mook, a skin for a typical Mary Sue protagonist, or a Big Bang Theory-level "nerd humor" punchline.  Play this goddam game before I sneak into your house and throw dusk moths on you while you sleep.

content:
Posted: January 14
												Klei is a special one in my book. They're building a small but distinct back catalog of highly appriciated games.Personally, I dislike their art-style and I couldn't care less about the story, but they score in the most important category.The games are fun, controls are intuitive and every game feels like something you haven't played before.One things for sure, there's definately some playtesting going around, because I never felt like the games were overly hard or ridiculously easy and I consider myself an average gamer.I never thought a 2d-sidescroller would be able to be an enjoyable stealth-game but Klei did it. It's not the best stealth game I've ever played but it's firmly in the top 10. The graphics are a bit a hit or miss-affair, but there's no denying that some thought have gone into them and they do the job more than adequate. Sound is ok but don't expect bucketloads of atmosphere.The gameplay is smooth, gently pulls you in and the difficulty curve is nigh on perfect. It's as much a puzzle as an actiongame like every decent stealth-game out there. I'll admit I'm not good at controlling 2d-scrolling games (except for the old flashback on which I'm the best player in the world :) ), but whenever I got in trouble, I never could curse the controls, it was me doing stupid stuff or trying the impossible and often both at the same time. I haven't progressed that much in the game but I've seen enough to know it'll be some time before I'm finished with this game. Simply because it's fun, unique and can hold it's own against the major stealth games I came to know and love.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												An excellent puzzle-platformer that oozes style, and features brilliant stealth-based gameplay. The animation and art style are bot fantastic, the cutscenes and story are well done, and the 'feel' is just right.Some of the levels, depending on your desire to achieve 100% completion, will cause you to pull your hair out. Don't fret, as each stage can be replayed upon completion. There's also a New Game+ mode for those who crave an even greater challenge.There are a few nitpicks. First, the game sometime doesn't recognize (i.e. award points for) hidden bodies, or certain other tasks. The handy-dandy 'restart from checkpoint' option nearly always solved this for me. Still, I thought it wise to give you all a head's up. Second, and I blame Steam/Steam Cloud for this, I -- and many others if you check Google -- lost my save at one point, completely negating approximately six hours of playtime. Mark of the Ninja is so good, I didn't really have an issue replaying it, but -- again -- it's worth mentioning.Perhaps due to the need to replay a significant portion of the  game, I do wish it was a level or two shorter. By the end, I was a little burned out. Nonetheless, I wholeheartedly recommend purchasing this title.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												Mark of the ninja is a 2D stealth-action platformer, and it is my favourite stealth game, although it is not without its flaws. While it may not have the most original story, it is your standard western ninja-flick, the beautiful animation makes the cutscenes stunning and engaging, and the talented voice actors make it even better. The gameplay itself is quite unique, because in most stealth games it is always a gamble about how far the guards can see or hear, or how far the grenade you've thrown will go etc. However, in Mark of the Ninja, it tells you all of these things that you need to know, making most, if not all, deaths simply user error, and not bad game design making it unfair. In the game you can choose your playstyle: sneaky sneaky, or kill people- and non leathal take-downs with the special dlc- and the game gives you upgrade paths for all of those playstyles. However, I feel that the game is a bit indecisive about the upgrades and playstyles, because while you get loads of points for completing a mission without killing people or being spotted, most of the upgrades are for the violent path, with far less benifitting a stealth approach. Personally, I prefer the violent path, purely because of the great takedown animations.The presentaion and artstyle of this game is amazing. It really adds to the atmosphere, and the fact that it is all hand drawn makes it even better to look at. When it comes to Klei's games (the company that made Mark of the Ninja) they have a really unique and eye-catching art style to all of their games, whilest all of it is unique, it still has that similar, colourful theme.Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who even has a passing interest in the stealth genre, and for stealth verterans looking for a challenge in the New Game Plus mode. It is also a good entry level stealth game, catering well for beginners and people who have only just discovered the genre.  Pros  Excellent gameplay Original art style Good for beginners and veterans Cons  Unoriginal story Some bugs and glitches Score  8.5/10

content:
Posted: July 23, 2013
												INB4 MARK PUNS (7 people already made them)But to be serious now, I've been looking towards this game since it's release and when I bought it, I received from it far more than I've expected. It reminds me of the older Splinter Cell game series (especially the ones made for cell phones which were pretty popular back in the days), but Mark of the Ninja has way more to offer. Altrough, this game isn't all about RUN INTO YOUR ENEMY FROM BEHIND AND KILL HIM. You must be observative, use your surroundings to your advantage, and sometimes even distract multiple enemies with noises in order to advance further.The further you get, the more upgrades will be available, tools you receive to kill or distract your enemies with, some special "styles" which give you advantage for a cost of carrying some of those items and even a side-story about the clan of the ninja's written in haiku's which you can collect in the given levels. Some of the cinematics are as well pretty stunning.Of course, completing levels with perfectance gives you bonus points which you can get yourself upgrades with. There's also side-objectives which are quite challenging, but on completion give you additional points. And if you fail to make any of the side-objectives, you can always restart from the checkpoints which are set every 1/6 to 1/10 of the levels. Especially fun is terrorizing the enemies with corpses of their dead teammates, SPOILER: They engage into friendly fire if you do that, which is hilarious to watch.. I'll give this game a 9.5 out of 10.It got a -0.5 from me because you can kill dogs in this. :( I should play this game again someday.

												The Plot - For me it's OK. It looks a little foreseeable at begining, but it acquires some philosophical aspects, such as the ninja code of honor, the most positive quality in my opinion, what creates a reflexive and excellent end.The Gameplay - The best feature in this game, Beacause there is a total freedom in the behavior of the player in the game. This one worth be played.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Mark of the Ninja is a great example of how much more important gameplay is than graphical fidelity. This is a familiar sentiment, but Mark of the Ninja embodies it. The control scheme with a 360-controller is excellent, and the game gently ramps up the difficulty as you gain proficiency with the controls. The length is perfect; the game never feels repetitious. A single playthough should take you 8-10 hours, and it's rewarding the entire way. There's decent replay value, as the game will give you higher scores, more tools and techniques, and Steam Achievements for more careful playstyles. I especially appreciate the leaderboard, where you can compare your performance to that of your Steam friends. There's another notable feature that's built into the gameplay that may go unnoticed, because it's an absence, not a feature: there is no difficulty slider. Mark of the Ninja offers exactly as much challenge as you want to take on. If you want a casual experience, the game is challenging but only rarely frustrating. If you want an expert-level challenge, there are challenges built into each level that you can attempt or ignore. For example, no kills, no detection, incapacitating certain soldiers, putting out every light, putting out no lights. There's no difficulty slider that puts in more or fewer enemeies,  or makes them more or less alert. It's a brilliant design. And - it does this on the fly. Some of these challenge goals appear mid-level. Two players can play the same level and have an entirely different experience. The game gives you just as much challenge as you would like to take on. Mark of the Ninja is a superbly designed game. Give it a go.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2013
												An amazing indie game made by Klei, its a stealth/action dependent on your actions.  The story is: You're a Ninja which has been marked with a tattoo which gives you exceptional skills and powers, you will however, eventually go mad due to the power you possess.  As the legend says, you will end your life to die with honor before you lose all of your control over yourself.  Your clan is attacked by Karajan, and you are you are the Ninja that has been Marked with the tattoo to take him down.  The artwork in the game is beautiful, there isn't much music but for the music that this game does have, its amazing, for the most part.  As for the game play you'll mostly be killing people via steal kills or the items at your disposal. Whenever you do something, you make a sound, you need to be aware of what you're doing, making sounds alerts guards, you do use this to your advantage as you can distract guards for you to be able to kill them, however, you can also end up having enemies notice you when you really don't want them to.  You do buy items that you unlock with honor you get in missions, you get honor from getting a certain number of points in a level, finding scrolls in the level, or doing different tasks, the upgrades you buy are items, upgrades for yourself, and different ways to kill your foes, which will generally make them much easier to kill.  You get 2 kinds of items, Distraction items which distract, knock out enemies, or one that lets you hide yourself from enemies, and Attack items which attack enemies, these range from spike traps to ravenous insects which will eat your target causing them to scream in horror and pain (alerting anyone within a large distance to the victim, and terrifying anyone that sees the target be killed).  Or, you could try to avoid all the enemies, there are different styles you can choose(after unlocking them) which change how your character plays.  Some styles include one that lets you run without making a sound but you don't get a sword meaning the only way you can kill enemies is through your items or the environment, another makes it so when an enemy sees a dead enemy, they become terrified making them easier to kill, the downside is you can't bring an distraction items.     The game does reward you for killing, but the game also rewards you for simply being hidden while an enemy passes by you if you do beat a finish without killing any enemies you get a large point bonus, the game does have a point system involved for different actions, I never cared for it, except to get the best rank, but you could put your score on the leader boards and see how your score holds up, but the leader board is filled with cheaters so its mostly just to compare with friends who also play the game.  I love this game and I feel like it is one of the best games of 2012.Too long didn't read?   The game has good artwork, the gameplay is fun, the little music the game has is great, and the fact that the game let's you decide how to play make it an amazing experience.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												I went into this game unsure of what to expect.  I've always loved Klei's art style, and while I utterly suck at Shank, I found its gameplay to be very tight and enjoyable.  However, I've had very little exeperience with stealth games and the hype for this was through the roof, which is usually setup for disappointment. I came out of my inital twenty hours with a new additoon to my favorite video games of all time.  Let me be the first to admit, this games narrative is probably its weakest aspect.  It attempts to emulate the kitschy ninja and martial arts movies of old, and while that's something I should love, I found the excectuion to be lacking.  A lot of the voice acting is pretty flat and there's a glaring thematic inconsisentcy to the gameplay's focus on true ninja techniques and the narrative's emphasis on the western misconception of "honor" among ninja.  However, that's easily overlooked thanks not only to the incredible job done with all other aesthetic qualities, but also the gameplay itself. This game is so ludicrously elegant.  So beautifully designed, fluid and engaging, that I almsot can't believe actual humans made it.  Humanity implies fallibility, and the core mechanics of this game have none that I can think of.  Every limitation is deliberate, every ability satisfying, every animation goregoud and fluid.  It all comes together to deliver on the game's central conciet: making you feel like a ninja.  Not an unstoppable badass with a hood and katana.  Not a one-man army that happens to dress like a feudal Japanese spy.  Not a barely-clothed cheesecake factory with a sharp fan who giggles and calls herself "kunoichi" while all the straight male gamers bend over backwards to call her a strong female character.  A NINJA.  An honest-to-god shadow warrior who strikes hard and vanishes into the night.  The core mechanics of this game and the vast majority of the way those mechanics are implemented are SUBLIME.  Unfortunately, there are some areas that are pretty "bleh."  In particular, the laser puzzles are fine when first introduced, but quickly become so tedious that I find myself ready to rip out all my hair at the roots and mash on the keyboard with my bloody disembodied scalp.  And there are some items that I pretty much never used due to how difficult it was to make proper use of them in the vast majority of situations.  But in the grand scheme of things, these are truly minor things, and all in all, this game is absolutely incredible.  I'd dare say it's a masterpiece.  One of ther finest blends of all the elements that make a game engaging and peerless in the way it presents a pop culture touchstone so often reduced to a generic mook, a skin for a typical Mary Sue protagonist, or a Big Bang Theory-level "nerd humor" punchline.  Play this goddam game before I sneak into your house and throw dusk moths on you while you sleep.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14
												Klei is a special one in my book. They're building a small but distinct back catalog of highly appriciated games.Personally, I dislike their art-style and I couldn't care less about the story, but they score in the most important category.The games are fun, controls are intuitive and every game feels like something you haven't played before.One things for sure, there's definately some playtesting going around, because I never felt like the games were overly hard or ridiculously easy and I consider myself an average gamer.I never thought a 2d-sidescroller would be able to be an enjoyable stealth-game but Klei did it. It's not the best stealth game I've ever played but it's firmly in the top 10. The graphics are a bit a hit or miss-affair, but there's no denying that some thought have gone into them and they do the job more than adequate. Sound is ok but don't expect bucketloads of atmosphere.The gameplay is smooth, gently pulls you in and the difficulty curve is nigh on perfect. It's as much a puzzle as an actiongame like every decent stealth-game out there. I'll admit I'm not good at controlling 2d-scrolling games (except for the old flashback on which I'm the best player in the world :) ), but whenever I got in trouble, I never could curse the controls, it was me doing stupid stuff or trying the impossible and often both at the same time. I haven't progressed that much in the game but I've seen enough to know it'll be some time before I'm finished with this game. Simply because it's fun, unique and can hold it's own against the major stealth games I came to know and love.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13
												although the story was not especially interesting to me, Mark of the Ninja made up for what it lacked in storytelling by providing one of the best stealth game experiences that i have ever played, brilliant character animations and fluid movement, along with inspired and detailed level designs, made the visual impression of this game unforgettable. the various gadgets, abilities and outfits, each perfectly suited to many different playstyles, prevent the game from becoming repetitive and allow you to approach every mission in whichever way you prefer. The special edition downloadable content also adds a new character to the game who can peform non-lethal takedowns, a much needed feature in the game, as well as including a developer commentary for the game, which i found very interesting as it gave me a new perspective on the each of the levels and characters, showing many of the decisions, stages, and inspirations for many aspects of the game. In general, this game perfectly captured the feeling and atmosphere of being a supernatural ninja infiltrating a high tech and corrupt security company.in this next section i have not mentioned names in order to keep spoilers to a minimum, but i will be discussing an event that occurs at the end of the story, so this is a warning for anyone who wishes to avoid spoiler materiala problem that i observed whilst playing the game was that the story's second antagonist was set up as corrupt and dishonorable, yet by the end of the game's story the player was tasked with the moral decision of choosing whether to kill him or one of the protagonists in the story, this struck me as odd because i personally felt no sense of moral dilemma, as the reasons to side with the fellow protagonist far outweighed the reasons to side with the character that, up until this point, i had considered the main villian for this part of the story. The decision you make of which character you kill is also seemingly pointless, as the credits roll immediately afterwards, however this is explained in the developer commentary, as they decided that it should be up to the players interpretation of which option was the right one, which is actually a reasonable decision for them to make, as the player is controlling the ninja, and a game should not tell a player that they are not playing the game properly because of a decision that they thought was the right thing to do.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												One shade separated from another, flashed through a corridor and clung to a massive pillar. A guard blinked and fixed his aim on that point. With a slow motion he switched on a flashlight mounted on his submachine gun and blinked again. Light beamed the pillar forcefully causing the myriads of shadows stampede.I am losing my senses - the guard thought.A feint movement of shade produced a blow so mighty yet discrete at the same time. The air was still when the guard collapsed.This is Mark of the Ninja. Precise execution, flawless mechanics and rapid tempo of this hit took its toll not only on unlucky guard. I was blown away too. Every single area of this game shines brightly and works extremely well together. Architecture of levels, atmospheric visuals and sound, brilliant ideas in mechanics, simple but existing story, skills, upgrades, unlocks and sleeping dogs. Not to prolong any more with the details you can probably find in any other review I can simply say: get it!Mark of the Ninja is the best game in it's genre of platformers (stealthy one here). It is also one of the best games ever in my private ranking. After you finish a last level of it and read cool developer diaries just start again in a new game+ because delving into virtual 2d world has never been so fascinating.Ninja style recommendation.

												This game really fills a niche I have been wanting filled since Tenchu! The gameplay is fantastic, and only gets more amazing each level. The multitude of ways to attack each situation is really incredible. I enjoyed leaving a blood bath in my wake, but you can avoid the guards etc. completely if you are stealthy enough. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Mark of the Ninja is a brilliant, well-made 2d stealth game. I don't usually care much about indie games. but I admit, this one is one of best indie games I've ever playedWith beautiful artistic environment, great level-design, cool story and voice-acting, and deep gameplay.The Art reminds me a lot of 2003's TMNT show. The lighting system is a top-notch.The gameplay is fluid, with so many approaches to take, wheather you like going all-out or being a complete ghost.During the missions, you are given a set of side quests to complete, a scrolls and artifacts to collect for perfect results.You can also upgrade your Ninja to have more abilities which really proves useful, and upgrade your weapons and tools and establish more stylish strategy. Oh, and there are a number of outfits to use, each one has unique gameplay style for different goals.The game also offers a dozen of hidden challenge rooms in the missions, which are really fun and aren't really heavily cryptic.If you decided to get this game, i recommend getting the special edition as well.The extra mission provides more challenge taking your sword, you have to rely on different approaches than what you would get used to in the main game. Also, the new items are extremely useful and cool.And for something new to me, I actually had fun reading The Developer Commentary pages during my playthrough.Something i haven't done before. It was really an interesting and fun read, I've learnt many things and i can see how much the developers worked hard into this game. I salute you guys.Art: 9.5/10Music: 8.5/10Atmosphere: 9.5/10Story: 8/10Gameplay: 9.5/10Overal: 9/10 "A Must-Play"

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												This game delivers one of my favorite stealth experiences of all time. Many stealth games leave you guessing as to the sightlines of enemies and how far some noise travels, but this game gives you every speck of information. It allows you to feel like a total badass when you hang just outside of an enemy's field of view to wait for the kill. You also have many methods of killing and sneaking, so there is plenty of replayability in running through the story with different playstyles. The art style . . . looks like Disney. Take this as you will, but this game looks like it was drawn by Disney. For one, that means that all motions are fluid and beautiful, but it can sometimes seem a little too cartoony for the "mature" vibe it gives off. The story is very "ehh," and the voiceacting can be a little off, but nonetheless, this games gets a recommendation from me.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												An excellent puzzle-platformer that oozes style, and features brilliant stealth-based gameplay. The animation and art style are bot fantastic, the cutscenes and story are well done, and the 'feel' is just right.Some of the levels, depending on your desire to achieve 100% completion, will cause you to pull your hair out. Don't fret, as each stage can be replayed upon completion. There's also a New Game+ mode for those who crave an even greater challenge.There are a few nitpicks. First, the game sometime doesn't recognize (i.e. award points for) hidden bodies, or certain other tasks. The handy-dandy 'restart from checkpoint' option nearly always solved this for me. Still, I thought it wise to give you all a head's up. Second, and I blame Steam/Steam Cloud for this, I -- and many others if you check Google -- lost my save at one point, completely negating approximately six hours of playtime. Mark of the Ninja is so good, I didn't really have an issue replaying it, but -- again -- it's worth mentioning.Perhaps due to the need to replay a significant portion of the  game, I do wish it was a level or two shorter. By the end, I was a little burned out. Nonetheless, I wholeheartedly recommend purchasing this title.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												Mark of the ninja is a 2D stealth-action platformer, and it is my favourite stealth game, although it is not without its flaws. While it may not have the most original story, it is your standard western ninja-flick, the beautiful animation makes the cutscenes stunning and engaging, and the talented voice actors make it even better. The gameplay itself is quite unique, because in most stealth games it is always a gamble about how far the guards can see or hear, or how far the grenade you've thrown will go etc. However, in Mark of the Ninja, it tells you all of these things that you need to know, making most, if not all, deaths simply user error, and not bad game design making it unfair. In the game you can choose your playstyle: sneaky sneaky, or kill people- and non leathal take-downs with the special dlc- and the game gives you upgrade paths for all of those playstyles. However, I feel that the game is a bit indecisive about the upgrades and playstyles, because while you get loads of points for completing a mission without killing people or being spotted, most of the upgrades are for the violent path, with far less benifitting a stealth approach. Personally, I prefer the violent path, purely because of the great takedown animations.The presentaion and artstyle of this game is amazing. It really adds to the atmosphere, and the fact that it is all hand drawn makes it even better to look at. When it comes to Klei's games (the company that made Mark of the Ninja) they have a really unique and eye-catching art style to all of their games, whilest all of it is unique, it still has that similar, colourful theme.Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who even has a passing interest in the stealth genre, and for stealth verterans looking for a challenge in the New Game Plus mode. It is also a good entry level stealth game, catering well for beginners and people who have only just discovered the genre.  Pros  Excellent gameplay Original art style Good for beginners and veterans Cons  Unoriginal story Some bugs and glitches Score  8.5/10

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												This game delivers one of my favorite stealth experiences of all time. Many stealth games leave you guessing as to the sightlines of enemies and how far some noise travels, but this game gives you every speck of information. It allows you to feel like a total badass when you hang just outside of an enemy's field of view to wait for the kill. You also have many methods of killing and sneaking, so there is plenty of replayability in running through the story with different playstyles. The art style . . . looks like Disney. Take this as you will, but this game looks like it was drawn by Disney. For one, that means that all motions are fluid and beautiful, but it can sometimes seem a little too cartoony for the "mature" vibe it gives off. The story is very "ehh," and the voiceacting can be a little off, but nonetheless, this games gets a recommendation from me.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Mark of the Ninja is a brilliant, well-made 2d stealth game. I don't usually care much about indie games. but I admit, this one is one of best indie games I've ever playedWith beautiful artistic environment, great level-design, cool story and voice-acting, and deep gameplay.The Art reminds me a lot of 2003's TMNT show. The lighting system is a top-notch.The gameplay is fluid, with so many approaches to take, wheather you like going all-out or being a complete ghost.During the missions, you are given a set of side quests to complete, a scrolls and artifacts to collect for perfect results.You can also upgrade your Ninja to have more abilities which really proves useful, and upgrade your weapons and tools and establish more stylish strategy. Oh, and there are a number of outfits to use, each one has unique gameplay style for different goals.The game also offers a dozen of hidden challenge rooms in the missions, which are really fun and aren't really heavily cryptic.If you decided to get this game, i recommend getting the special edition as well.The extra mission provides more challenge taking your sword, you have to rely on different approaches than what you would get used to in the main game. Also, the new items are extremely useful and cool.And for something new to me, I actually had fun reading The Developer Commentary pages during my playthrough.Something i haven't done before. It was really an interesting and fun read, I've learnt many things and i can see how much the developers worked hard into this game. I salute you guys.Art: 9.5/10Music: 8.5/10Atmosphere: 9.5/10Story: 8/10Gameplay: 9.5/10Overal: 9/10 "A Must-Play"

content:
Posted: July 23, 2013
												INB4 MARK PUNS (7 people already made them)But to be serious now, I've been looking towards this game since it's release and when I bought it, I received from it far more than I've expected. It reminds me of the older Splinter Cell game series (especially the ones made for cell phones which were pretty popular back in the days), but Mark of the Ninja has way more to offer. Altrough, this game isn't all about RUN INTO YOUR ENEMY FROM BEHIND AND KILL HIM. You must be observative, use your surroundings to your advantage, and sometimes even distract multiple enemies with noises in order to advance further.The further you get, the more upgrades will be available, tools you receive to kill or distract your enemies with, some special "styles" which give you advantage for a cost of carrying some of those items and even a side-story about the clan of the ninja's written in haiku's which you can collect in the given levels. Some of the cinematics are as well pretty stunning.Of course, completing levels with perfectance gives you bonus points which you can get yourself upgrades with. There's also side-objectives which are quite challenging, but on completion give you additional points. And if you fail to make any of the side-objectives, you can always restart from the checkpoints which are set every 1/6 to 1/10 of the levels. Especially fun is terrorizing the enemies with corpses of their dead teammates, SPOILER: They engage into friendly fire if you do that, which is hilarious to watch.. I'll give this game a 9.5 out of 10.It got a -0.5 from me because you can kill dogs in this. :( I should play this game again someday.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
 Probably one the best games on Steam. I bought this game on sale for ~3$, but would recommend it at full price -  it's worth every single cent! I usually don't like playing stealth games, but this one is different. Having played Shank and Shank 2 before and knowing Klei Entertainment is behind this game too I had thought that it would be a classic beat-em up sidescroller, but boy, was I wrong. You have to play smart and think like a ninja. If you go straight to face-2-face battle with the enemies chances are you'll get yourself killed in no time, but if you think and make a strategy you'll probably kill the foe with one mouse swipe.The graphics are awesome and the animation is very fluid. The game uses the same engine as the Shank series, which is a plus.All in all, Klei Entertainment and Microsoft Studios did a wonderful job with this one and any arcade/platformer/stealth game lover should have this gen in his/her library. 10/10

content:
Posted: July 6, 2013
												In Mark of the Ninja, you play as a hardworking family man who is living the American dream. On level 2, when your wife tasks you with taking out the recycling, the game takes a dark turn as you, the player, discovers on the door of your 4 bedroom suburban home the dreaded mark of the ninja. Ancient Japanese folklore states that those who once lived a dark path cannot escape their judgement among the gods, and it is the task of the order of the ninja to mark such people and bring them to justice. In levels 3-10 you proceed to dodge the ninja's attempts on your life such as while waiting in line at the grocery or having to outrun the ninja while you're getting your license renewed at the department of motor vehicles while still having to perform up-to-par as a driver to the ministry's expectations. Narratively, the game is very interesting, as the player discovers more about their dark past and wrestles with mature themes such as forgiveness and regret. While the mark of the ninja is very dangerous to get in real life, don't be afraid to get the mark of the ninja on steam, you'll be safe from the ninja on steam.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												A arcade-stealth combination with excellent detail but somewhat tired, cliche story. Recommended with DLC - 7/10Mark of the Ninja takes side-scrolling arcade mechanics, emphasizes the stealth possibilities, places them inside a boyish story of ninjas, mercenaries and bandits in fantastic, cartoony landscapes of Japan, Central Europe and Middle East. I wouldn't consider this a pure stealth game. Sure, patience and careful observation of the environment are necessary, but there are many places where speedy thumbwork on the controller is necessary. My personal tastes lean towards the former but the combination is still appealing.After completing the campaign the levels can be replayed with some visual aids toned down. Although I've only started this now (the initial completion of the campaign took about 15-16 hours), I like it somewhat more than the starting mode. I now have the freedom to try out either more direct combat modes or pure 'ghosting' levels.The DLC fleshes the story out more and adds director's commentary. I like this kind of 'behind the scenes' stuff and would recommend it as well as the main game. I have to say I bought the game at a discount, but I think it's worth the full price. The DLC, perhaps, is better got at a discount.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												It's hard to write this review other than saying, "Just buy it!"I got it for $4.49 with the special edition package during the Winter Sale. If I had known about this game before hand, I would have paid full price; it's that good.My Impression:I walked in expecting of a 2D stealth-action game with great mechanics and a fair amount of freedom with each level. This offered that. I expected to be able to stealth around a platformer as a ninja and kill my opponents. This offered that. It met my expectations.Positive:+ Best in genre of 2D stealth games+ Great graphics+ Great mechanics with different ways of killing your opponents+ Different builds you can use (it's possible to beat any map with an build, whatever suits your style)+ Strategy involved in using objects and builds to kill you opponents+ Replayability with the scoring of each "chapter"Cons:- The story starts off slow- Have to finish the game to appreciate the storyReason for 10/10:Lack of an immersive story9/10Recommended to anyone who just wants to have fun. It's been awhile since a game was just fun to me. Most are actually fun but usually have sort of grind mechanic which can reduce how much I enjoy the game. This game keeps me entertained and wanting more. Easy recommendation.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Mark of the Ninja was a pleasant surprise that provided me with a great deal of entertainment for only a pittance (around $3). It stars a Ninja imbued with enchanted tattoos that give him special powers but also curse him with increasing madness, whose goal is to complete a mission of assassination and then take his own life before he loses the last remnants of his sanity. The graphics and music are all appropriately ninja-themed which really helps to draw you into the overall atmosphere of the game. Most characters are fairly well animated for 2d and I was impressed by the level of effort put into the cinematics between levels (they had kind of a Samurai Jack vibe). The game also features helpful sound cues for when enemies are moving around in other rooms and for when you have been seen.Since this is intended as a stealth game, gameplay consists of you finding your way through each level while avoiding detection and removing any obstacles, human or otherwise. Many of the areas had multiple routes that sometimes took me in completely different directions which I thought was a nice touch and added to overall replay-ability. Of course, it wouldn’t be a ninja game if you didn’t also have an array of ninja tools to deal with pesky enemies and inconvenient light sources. Besides your darts, you also have methods of distraction and extermination, and can customize your loadout at various points denoted by a hanging flag in each level. You will only have a few abilities at the start of the game, but you can unlock more by completing bonus challenges, finding secrets, and completing objectives. The only gripe I have with Mark of the Ninja is that the controls can be a little quirky at times especially when moving between horizontal and vertical planes with contextual button commands. This wasn’t really a big deal but it did take me until near the end of the game before I finally got used to it. The game is also a bit short, but considering how cheap it is that’s not really a problem.So, if you’re in the mood for a stealth-action ninja-themed game, try picking this one up. You might end up just as pleasantly surprised as I was!

content:
Posted: December 17, 2012
												Very surprised by how well it was done for being a small indie sidescroller. There are many cool ways to kill, and many different tools in your arsenal. All aspects of the stealth aspect are done right, from light, to sight, to sound. There are a few minor problems. I would do the same part over numerous times and do the exact same thing and I would get caught sometimes and not others. There is sometimes a flaw in the lack of consistency. The levels all seem very similar as the terrain is black and there isn't much of a different to to notice. The length is not bad for being a lower costing price. It is nice how there are multiple ways to go and get to a part. This also backfires however, when you are supposed to find things scattered about the level to complete challenges it is usually all but impossible with how many different ways there are to go which can make the levels confusing. Since you stealth kill people very often, it gets boring to see the same 3 animations for 7 hours. Theres really only way to kill people and it leaves very littile in improvisation. Most of the abilities are locked through the entire game which makes sense. I think it is meant to be so you replay but that is a cheap way of doing it as I would like to see what my guy can do through the game. You also get very little honor to unlock new things and many of the abilities are simple upgrades on equipment and usually uninspired. The controls sometimes screw up. Certain times I would want to jump down and it would make me go into a vent instead. Other times I want to jump off a ledge and it would make me stick to it and just transfer to the underside. Other times I would be right behind someone to stealth kill them and I would press the button and it would just hit them for no reason. All-in-all this game deserved the good reviews that it got and  itusually does stealth right. Once again a lesson for all those♥♥♥♥♥♥indie developers that keep putting out 1990's pixelated japense rpgs or other crappy aracade side-scrolling shooters. You can make an inspired and original game. No need for more games that look like♥♥♥♥♥♥and are the same as every other one out there. 8.5/10

												Hell friggin' yeah!This oughta be my favorite stealth game ever and I'm gonna explain in a few lines why I love it so much. First off, its art style reminds me of cartoon TV shows I used to enjoy watching through my childhood years, like Avatar and many Cartoon Network-based shows, so that's a big plus for me. Then the gameplay - the controls are very responsive, its mechanics aren't hard to get a hold of, every level feels like a bit of something new and there's mostly always several options to deal with any problem that the player has to face so the game never gets boring. Manipulating, terrorizing and executing enemies is pretty satisyfing, and many different execution moves and several animations for each make sure that killing people doesn't become a tedious chore. Checkpoints aren't scarce and shops are always accessible in case the player wants to switch loadouts mid-mission. Exploration feels rewarding thanks to the side-objectives that every mission has and as well as the goodies that can be found at distant parts of any level, like challenge rooms. The soundwork is freakin' A, especially the soundtrack which is remarkable and very memorable. Finally, the game has a nice ammount of achievements and their cool names and fantastic icons make it particularly pleasing whenever one of them gets unlocked and pops up on the player's screen during the play.I'm aiming to touch up on this text once I get the Special Edition DLC but I hope that even at its current state it's quite evident from my review that this game is a fantastic title and very much worth the buy.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												Mark of the Ninja is not a game I should have liked. I'm not an action fan and my reflexes aren't what they once were. Frankly, I tend to suck at games like this nowadays. So I tend to avoid games like this.But this is an exceptionally crafted game and one I am glad I didn't miss. Truly, in all areas - art, sound, gameplay mechanics, story - it's a wonderful experience. The stealth mechanics are fun, fair and challenging. Your tool belt of goodness allows you to overcome any obstacle, whether by stealth or by sword. In fact you can get through most maps with either sword or stealth and having multiple ways to approach a problem makes it a lot of fun and adds to the replayability of the game. The maps are lovingly hand crafted to supply some really fun challenges. The story is also interesting and compelling with one of the better endings I've experienced in quite some time.In short, this game is highly recommended. You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2013
												In Mark of the Ninja, you play as a hardworking family man who is living the American dream. On level 2, when your wife tasks you with taking out the recycling, the game takes a dark turn as you, the player, discovers on the door of your 4 bedroom suburban home the dreaded mark of the ninja. Ancient Japanese folklore states that those who once lived a dark path cannot escape their judgement among the gods, and it is the task of the order of the ninja to mark such people and bring them to justice. In levels 3-10 you proceed to dodge the ninja's attempts on your life such as while waiting in line at the grocery or having to outrun the ninja while you're getting your license renewed at the department of motor vehicles while still having to perform up-to-par as a driver to the ministry's expectations. Narratively, the game is very interesting, as the player discovers more about their dark past and wrestles with mature themes such as forgiveness and regret. While the mark of the ninja is very dangerous to get in real life, don't be afraid to get the mark of the ninja on steam, you'll be safe from the ninja on steam.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												I have seen tons of people recommend Mark of the Ninja, and now I know why. Mark of the Ninja is a great platformer and an even better stealth game! Mark of the Ninja has you playing a ninja warrior who has been given special powers by his clan, in order to avenge them, these powers however are slowly driving him mad. The game itself is done in a pretty unique art style for a stealth platformer, and its an art style I have found myself enjoying as I play. Mechanically you are able to spring and grapple through the levels trying to remain out of sight of enemys. You can chose to try to complete the level without killing for a large bonus at the end, or you can massacre your way through the level building as many points as you can.  There are collectibles hidden levels as well, such as hidden challenge rooms, artifacts, and other secondary objectives you can collect to learn more of the lore. The character is equipped with a variety of gear including a sword for executions and assassinations, firecrackers for distractions, throwing darts for distractions and interacting with items from a distance, and a few other items you will get throughout the game. This leaves the options open to play how you want, kill no one, kill a lot, or just stealth through like a ghost. The one takeaway from this is to NOT go in guns blazing, even when you do fight, keep it like a ninja. Overall I would recommend Mark of the Ninja to fans of stealth games and paltformers, you have definitely got yourself a good game here!

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Mark of the Ninja was a pleasant surprise that provided me with a great deal of entertainment for only a pittance (around $3). It stars a Ninja imbued with enchanted tattoos that give him special powers but also curse him with increasing madness, whose goal is to complete a mission of assassination and then take his own life before he loses the last remnants of his sanity. The graphics and music are all appropriately ninja-themed which really helps to draw you into the overall atmosphere of the game. Most characters are fairly well animated for 2d and I was impressed by the level of effort put into the cinematics between levels (they had kind of a Samurai Jack vibe). The game also features helpful sound cues for when enemies are moving around in other rooms and for when you have been seen.Since this is intended as a stealth game, gameplay consists of you finding your way through each level while avoiding detection and removing any obstacles, human or otherwise. Many of the areas had multiple routes that sometimes took me in completely different directions which I thought was a nice touch and added to overall replay-ability. Of course, it wouldn’t be a ninja game if you didn’t also have an array of ninja tools to deal with pesky enemies and inconvenient light sources. Besides your darts, you also have methods of distraction and extermination, and can customize your loadout at various points denoted by a hanging flag in each level. You will only have a few abilities at the start of the game, but you can unlock more by completing bonus challenges, finding secrets, and completing objectives. The only gripe I have with Mark of the Ninja is that the controls can be a little quirky at times especially when moving between horizontal and vertical planes with contextual button commands. This wasn’t really a big deal but it did take me until near the end of the game before I finally got used to it. The game is also a bit short, but considering how cheap it is that’s not really a problem.So, if you’re in the mood for a stealth-action ninja-themed game, try picking this one up. You might end up just as pleasantly surprised as I was!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Mark of the Ninja is a stealth focused side scrolling 2.5D platforming game.  In it you play a Ninja on his quest to avenged his clan, then other stuff happens (sorry, spoilers if I said more)Graphics: 9Well done 2D graphics are timeless.  In 10 or 20 years we will look at this game and still say it looks good.Sound: 8Sound effects are spot on, if a bit repetitive.Music: 5Music is pretty basic but sets the mood nicely.  You won't be irritated by it, but you probably won't be searching for a sound track either.Gameplay: 10This is stealth done right.  You get all the tools you need to play exactly how you want.  You can run up to people and kick them in the face, you can hide and kill them quietly.  Or you can leave them to go back to their homes and wives and children and just sneak passed them.  The choice is yours.Impression: 10When you start the game, you will immediately be impressed with the scale of the game.  You will see many many paths you can take, and you will have many options on how to defeat the enemy or get passed them.  The game allows you to work as fast or as slow as you want.Value: This is a great game in the 10 dollar range and you will have lots of fun.Summary:If you love puzzles and stealth, you should get this game.Note that although the game supports keyboard and mouse, it is difficult to use.  I suggest using an x-input controller instead.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												I recently reviewed this game for my game review blog, Five Penny Review. If you enjoy this review, please visit my page:http://fivepennyreview.blogspot.com/2013/08/mark-of-ninja.htmlWhat sets this game apart?While I have certainly played first-person shooter games that had some reliance on stealth, I have never played many games that would be considered a part of the stealth genre.  The idea of a stealth game designed as a 2D platformer intrigued me, so I tried Mark of the Ninja during the Steam sale and was not disappointed.  While many stealth games seem to devolve into combat at some point, it is fully optional in Mark of the Ninja, and its system is highly tuned to allow you to emphasize stealth and movement.  If you are the type that prefers killing everything in sight, you can still functionally play the game as long as you do so carefully.  The art style is creative and complements the story well, and the cut scenes are generally well composed.What is the difficulty factor?While this game does a good job of pausing to offer instruction when new mechanics are introduced, the controls for the PC version are not discussed and can be a bit challenging as a result.  Once you experiment enough to figure out how everything works, the mouse control actually makes your movement and aim very natural.  Mark of the Ninja is a fairly difficult game as you progress, largely because of how unforgiving it can be.  It does not take much to kill you if you get caught, and if the alarm sounds it causes a huge loss of points that make it difficult to complete all of the tasks for the level.  With that said, the game is also as hard as you make it, as maximizing your points, completing side missions, and collecting all of the hidden scrolls are all completely optional.  When you do complete the game, the New Game + mode offers an entirely new level of difficulty, even less forgiving and relying much more on your ability to be aware of your surroundings and react quickly.Does it use media effectively?The art style utilized by the game is strange, but highly effective.  The game uses smooth cartoonish animation that complements both the style and story, especially considering the story elements involving scrolls and tattoos and the connections in the art style.  The voice acting and music are good enough, but nothing spectacular, especially with the often mediocre dialogue.  The place where this game really shines, however, is in the mechanical visuals and subtle sounds.  The game represents sounds with a ripple effect, revealing when enemies make noise near you and letting you know how far the sounds you make reach, and shows the visual range of enemies with a simple cone before them.  The use of subtle sounds such as footsteps, light switches, doors, and vents play an equally important role, especially in the New Game + mode where the sound ripples no longer appear.Best moment in the game?While the cut scenes have their good moments, the gameplay is really where this game shines.  As you unlock new styles, there are some really neat effects in the gameplay, and for me the most interesting is the Path of Nightmares.  In this mode, it becomes easier to trigger the “terrorized” condition in enemies, resulting in the enemies randomly shooting at any little noise, or running and screaming.  This adds another element to the game, as you discover creative ways to terrify the enemies.Who needs to play this game?Mark of the Ninja can be played in a variety of ways and can appeal to a variety of different players.  Players who enjoy stealth games like the Tenchu series will likely enjoy it.  Players who enjoy classic platformers will get a lot of enjoyment out of the puzzle-platforming sections, especially the catacombs.  The New Game + mode is extremely challenging, while playing the standard game without going for a high score can be fun to just play around.  It is available on Xbox Live and Steam.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												With a retro 2D design and some very hardcore stealth elements, Mark of the Ninja is a unique game in what has become an all too accessible genre. Too many modern "stealth" games have a feeling of being overly simplified and/or too accesible and forgiving. Despite the simple 2D style, Mark of the Ninja is a true hardcore stealth game that favours patience and precision whilst completely punishing players that try to stray from stealth. In otherwords, it does not try to cater to the "casual gamer" or allow you to take an "action" option but sticks to what made the stealth genre in the first place and takes pride in it's niche appeal.Update: I have cleared the game and upon replaying missions I have discovered an action option is available as you can unlock an armoured outfit (I have not played the game ever with that choice so I am unsure as to whether the armour outfit doubles your health or trebles it etc.)That said, there are another 6-8 outfits and they all have stealth as their main focus (one makes footsteps completely silent but removes your sword, one allows double gadget capcity etc.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												In a time when stealth segments are merely tacked onto any game, and never really expanded upon, MotN comes out and fills a stealth genre gap that greatly needed filling. Not only does it do that, it does so masterfully, with strong attention to all of the things that can make or break a stealth game. The art deco inspired aesthetics fit the japanese and urban settings surprisingly well, characters animate great and special attention is given to each locale in order to accommodate the stealth based nature of the game. A very important aspect of any stealth game is the sound design, this one nails it, it has a somber, unobtrusive score and slick audio cues for situations when a silent pursuit is close to turn into an unwanted confrontation. The mechanics and items are varied and tend to bolster the options available for handling situations. You'll rarely, if ever, get bored of what's being offered.Ummm... Yeah, you should play this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												Had already played the game in a friend's pc while in college, but decided to give it another go with the new Special Edition. Needless to say that I enjoyed it very much on the first time.The GOOD:It's a very well made game, where you play as a ninja (duhh) seeking revenge on an organization who tried to erradicate his Ninja's Order.It's a 2D platforming game, with its core lying in stealth. The prime example of this is that in some levels you can play without killing any enemy soldiers (If you choose to play that way). Climbing walls, using a hook, distractions with spikes and darts, you name it. There's a good variety of moves you can pull and it never feels underwhelming.The story arc has some minor twists along the way to keep it interesting and by the end of it all, the game leaves you with some questions and pertinent thoughts about your character. Not the stellar part of the game, but it's solid nonetheless.The soundtrack is good and blends well with the vibe of the game, enhancing its atmosphere.THE BAD:If there's anything I disliked its got to be the lack of multiplayer. Some alternative (dreams, allucinations, wtv) co-op missions would be a major plus and could give players other kind of challenges. They even had a second major character (Ora) who would fit nicely.& THE UGLY:If you try to fight head-to-head, you might as well say your last prayers. If you can't get behind stealthy, patient gameplay, you will not enjoy this game.

												What a game! At first I didn't think this game would be that good but I was completely wrong! This game is very enjoyable from start to finish. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												This is the first Klei game I ever played, and my GABEN was it good. Mark of the Ninja is a Stealth Platformer, and  it features a rather heavy emphasis on creatively killing your foes and hiding their bodies. Of course, since you're a ninja, you have various tools at you disposal, but your main weapon is your katana. You use it for executions (which involve pushing the control stick in one direction and pushing a button) and you can use it to finish off any foes you may have done damage to. Now, if you were stuck doing the same stuff every mission, the game would get stale, which is where new costumes come in! They can be used for everything from making executions easier, to making you an (almost) complete ghost to your enemies! This brings variety to the game, and WAY more replayability than you'd think. Oh, and did I forget to mention that this game has New Game Plus, which makes the game harder and forces you to think ahead before killing someone. Really good for people who liked Stealth ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Deluxe and other games of the sort.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2013
												*INITIAL IMPRESSIONS*I'll be the first one to admit, I don't have much of a mind for stealth games (Dishonored being the only stealth game I well and truly enjoyed), Mark of the Ninja is a hardcore stealth title. There is no actual combat, meaning if the player is spotted then you have to run, hide and accept the penalty to your final score. I like the concept of sticking to the shadows and utilizing the environment to move from point to point to avoid being seen, the player can climb to higher areas, hide in vents, duck behind cover or create a distraction to keep out of the sightlines of the patrolling guards. What I dislike about MotN is how the kills are managed, utilizing one of my greatest gaming pet-peeves, quick-time events. When you approach an enemy and click on them to begin your attack, the game will give you a split-second warning to slide your mouse either to the left or the right, a successful attempt will give you a silent assassination while failure to complete the event will end up making a lot of noise and attracting nearby guards. (This is especially bad if you're like me and you can never immediately figure out left from right on the spot. Don't you DARE judge me).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												How 2D Stealth Action Platformers should be...wait, this is the only one?  Dammit...  Ok,  so  your a ninja.  You sneak around and eff people up and do other ninja-y type things all the while taking revenge on the weird megacorporation/para-military organization that slaughtered your clan.   The sheer amount of gameplay elements that affect stealth in this game are just as mind boggling as the amount of options you have to kill with.  All of your enemies have specific detection ranges (which are visible and can be gauged)  that are affected by sound and light.  Just about everything you do in this game short of moving at your slowest pace generates sound of varying levels, sometimes to your benefit.   Also there's a wealth of unlockables and upgrades that add to the gameplay, from new weapons and tools to magic tattoos and special uniforms  or just unlocking new moves and abilities.  Each stage also has several different ways you can play it and a high-score system shared between you and friends to not only encourages you to go back to old stages and try out new things but also is a good way to sit down and be competitive with your friends when not actually playing together.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2012
												Earlier this year I said that FTL would likely go down as my favorite indie game of 2012, however I didn't expect Mark of the Ninja to come along. I wasn't even fully sure if MotN was indie, due to the polish and depth of content. I have played many titles from big-name developers that weren't even close to this level of competency. Enough rambling, on to the game... The gameplay is somewhere between Thief: The Dark Project and 16-bit side scrollers of the 90s. There is a bit of trial and error, but it's rarely frustrating and victory always feels rewarding. Nevermind the fact that there is almost always a number of solutions to each problem, the game was never repetitive enough to get boring, even after beating it twice for all of the achievements. Very few games balance repetition and play time so well. In addition, the interesting art style (very much Penny Arcade inspired) with tight controls and decent plot make this a solid must buy for anyone that likes stealth or side scrolling combat games.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2013
												Awesome game!! Great stealth platformer. Gameplay never got dull playing through the story. New Game+ mode for more challenge. I was pretty impressed with the ending, surprised...and impressed. I'll definately play through the game again on New Game+ (you keep your gear :P)Replayability is pretty good, since you have a nice selection of ninja tools and outfits, both of which will change your style of play thru a level. Other things you might like (NON-STORY RELATED SPOILER ALERT): Stealth kills (from behind, behind a door, underneath in a vent, above, from a grapple hook, from a dumpster, from a side vent...), spike traps, hallucinagenic darts, man-eating insects, various distraction tools, teleport (pretty much, imagine a flash step from Bleach), caltrops, various ways to terrorize the enemy, making an ememy accidentally shoot his ally while freaked out, and more! Enjoy!

Posted: February 1, 2014
												At first the game is a little hard to get into, but this is mostly attributed to a lack of items to utilize in the early levels. Once you finish the first few levels and start unlocking new equipment the game takes a giant leap forward in the versatility of playstyles offered. It took me a  solid 20hours of gameplay for the first run through to unlock everything, afterwards you can start a new game plus with a higher degree of difficulty. A surprisingly strong point of the game was it's story, incredibly well written and executed. Overall I have to say this game is worth full price, special addition included, perhaps even more. A lot of care went into this game and you can feel it at every turn. It has definitely earned a place as one of the best games I have ever played.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												This game was great, I never really liked stealth that much in games, not disliked, just prefered other playstyles, so when Mark of the Ninja came up on steam sale I was unsure however the other glowing reviews swayed it. The cartoon style immediately put me off; how can you have a serious stealth game when it looks like a childrens program? But after the first bloody kill I was won over. The cartoon style works, it may not be your favorite but you'll soon get over it with gameplay as engaging as this is, however you want to play the game you will find it rewarding. Whether you wish to leap over heads not hurting a fly or wish to leave a trail of death and destruction in you're wake the game gives you points which in turn can be used to unlock various things; either equipment or abilities. That is another aspect of the game I love, the upgrades, while none of them completely change your character you can use various combinations to result in a very different playing experience. The story isn't brilliant but heck you can't expect them to get everything right! GIve this game a go, I promise you won't be disapointed

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Mark of the Ninja is a 2D stealth game, which might be incredibly fun for those who are into stealth or side-scrolling action games. What interests me most is that this game renders a wide range of ninja gadgets that can be extremely useful for either non-lethal or lethal play styles. Sometimes I feel like I am the ninja version of Sam Fisher who distracts the enemy sniper by shooting out the lights with Shurien, and then sneaks pass the guards under the cover of smoke bomb. Like all the stealth games, there are various routes available in this game for players to choose, and such mechanism is amazingly well done in a 2D Platformer. Finally, it is strongly recommended that play Mark of the Ninja with a controller, because the keyboard is less competent as a controller in such kind of action game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2013
												Mark of the Ninja is a slick and stylish stealth action platformer.You infiltrate and assassinate your way through 12 gorgeously designed levels. The art is beautiful and the animations are slick. There is a range of environments, each with stunning vibrant parallax scrolling backgrounds offsetting the generally monochrome foreground.You start out with a relatively simple set of moves, introducing you to how stealth works in the game; Enemies have vision cones, moving quickly makes sound which draws enemies, you can hide behind environmental objects like vases and dumpsters, slipping through vents and setting up ambushes.The game slowly increases your equipment and move set (all of which can be customised) as you play. Each level has challenges for you to attempt, each of which unlocks a token you can spend on upgrading your gear. Complete enough of certain challenge types will unlock new costumes which include a gear restriction or boon. For example, completing 3 'Terror' challenges unlocks a gear set that makes you run without making any noise, but you lose your sword, forcing you to a fast and non-lethal playstyle.The story is relatively simplistic, but presented in short stylized cutscenes that work well. The story has a twist with a choice at the end, but it is nothing earth-shattering and not really the focus of the experience. The joy here is in the gameplay, the smooth controls (even if playing with a keyboard and mouse) and the art.After completion you unlock a new game plus mode, which increases the number of guards and increases the difficulty.
