Posted: February 17, 2014
												Easily one of the best stealth games ever made. I say this even though I was absolutely terrible at the game. Controller is a must, the keyboard controls just seem too clunky. The art style is amazing, and the AI of the enemies is almost spot on. My only complaint is the extreme diversity of accents, all of which obviously sound like Americans attempting to do an accent. Either I really sucked at the game, or you have to play the game several times through in order to really unlock your options on various gameplay styles. The endings are way too short on one hand, yet absolutely perfect on the other. This game is a must buy for fans of 2D platforming. IT EVEN HAS A BOX!!! (Metal Gear lovers rejoice!)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Overall rating: 8/10++ Excellent, forgiving checkpoint system+ Intuitive controls (especially the fact that you can't fall off a platform accidentally, without pressing space)+ Seals give extra challenge to already completed levels, offering more hours of gameplay and enjoyment+ Well made cartoon-like graphics+ Enables such an impatient person like me to wait happily for tens of seconds to wait for a perfect assasination opportunity+ It is fun to tease the guards+ Each level is a puzzle with many solutions+/- The level select is actually cleverly designed. However, it took me over 15 hours to figure out how it works (=Click the buildings) Dunno if it's just me or is it really weird- Automatical, uncontrollable and annoying vision/sight system*- Moving the corpses or targetting the grappling points near other interact objecs is irritatingly broken- Unnecessarily bloody*however, the checkpoint system compensates this fault partially: even if a guard saw you from somewhere you didn't see yet, you can always restart at the last checkpoint which is at most a couple of minutes ago.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Mark of the Ninja is a truly satisfying game; in story, style and gameplay it doesn't fail to impress.The story is mainly presented through cutscenes, or given out as monologues by your companion, but for the exploring ninjas there are extra tastes of backstory in the form of scrolls hidden in every level. The plot itself isn't complex, but is engaging, original and well written.Graphically, Mark of the Ninja offers some beautifully crafted levels. From the home of the ninja clan with its arching bridges, majestic halls and peaceful gardens; to the windswept ruins of a desert city where the ground is littered with traps and the high perches are home to mercenary snipers.MotNs stealth-based gameplay is well integrated with the artistic style, where shadows are your friend but so is a brightly lit chandelier - when an enemy chances upon a body left below it, and a single throwing knife turns the chandelier into a weapon. With the tools available, you've got a huge amount of freedom in both how you achieve your goals and make your way around the levels. You'll find yourself experimenting with ways to take out enemies or just distract them, even.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												To start: I used to add a header to these reviews, but since it often made the review too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery page.Gameplay: I never really was all that great at the Stealth genre, given my very guns-a-blazing kind of playstyle. Nevertheless, I usually have a lot of fun with the games. Mark of the Ninja is one of the most fun stealth games that I've played in a long time, as well as being one of the most immersive. The reason why is because of the stage design. Stages are absolute monsters that sometimes feel like a Super Metroid level than anything else. This game has a lot of exploration capabilities as well as plenty of non-linear apporaches you can take to meet objectives. There's even plenty of items to suit your playstyle. Do you wanna have fun scaring the pants off of enemies? String up bodies on grapple points. Are you a fan of the "out of sight, out of mind" mentality of guard AI? There's a suit that allows you to have full motion silence with the tradeoff of not being able to bring a sword with you. I'm more of a fan of going undetected and (preferably) not killing anyone, as I feel that stays truest to the stealth genre as a whole. However, if combat becomes a necessity, you could always hack your way out of a scenario.While I hardly did any fighting myself, the enemies seem to have pretty good AI whenever they've caught a glance at you, often backing up for reinforcements then pushing hard. There's also enough enemy variety to keep things interesting, but most of the time the thing that makes the game interesting are the stages themselves. Usually I get a bit annoyed whenever a game doesn't have any boss fights, but I wasn't that annoyed with it in this game, as an actual boss would've felt counter-intuitive to the design of the game. As far as the challenge of this game, I could see this being pretty easy for the stealth savant, but for the average person, I think the difficulty is just about right, if a bit too easy at the beginning. I think that the game could've done with a few less checkpoints per area so that you really have to slow down and not make things a trial and error fest, but I could also see the reasoning for the checkpoints. Checkpoints can screw you over at times, although this only happened to me once (a checkpoint put me in front of an enemy, ruining my chances for a no detect for that level), so be sure to take it easy for a couple of seconds once you see the checkpoint symbol.Apart from that, there really isn't too much more to talk about. It's a stealth game with a ton of great design sensibilities, it allows you to take things however you want to, and it's overall just a really fun game that's definitely worth your time. 10/10.Story: Everything up to the ending: pretty not bad, but not anything terribly memorable. The ending: should not be as good as it was. No seriously, dat ending. Actually, in retrospect, one of the main purposes of the plot up until the ending seems to be setting seeds for the final areas. As for the characters, they're kind of prototypical Japanese ninja movie characters, but oh well. Dat ending. 8/10.Graphics: I don't need to tell you that this game is absolutely phenomenal looking. You've got eyes. As for the technical aspects, the game fullscreened to my native resolution of 1080p without any hassle. Also, if you do happen to skip cutscenes, you may find that areas lag for a bit but then sort themselves out afterward. It's only a minor annoyance, since once you get past those spots, the game runs at a perfect 60FPS. 5/5.Sound: The soundtrack is pretty dang good, and once again, the ending is the thing that really takes the cake. Most of it is pretty ambient stuff, but it does a very good job at setting the mood. Fortunately, there weren't any sound glitches I experienced. As for the voice acting, it works fine. It's good enough. No award winning material, but hey, we can't expect that from everything. Disappointingly, it doesn't seem like the Special Edition comes with the soundtrack, but oh well; that's what Youtube is for. 5/5.Overall scores are: 10/8/5/5; cumulative score of 9.3/10. I noticed that this review ended up being a lot shorter than a lot of my others. Honestly, I think that's because I don't really have anything else to say other than, "It's good. You should go get it."

content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												MotW hits that weird stealth uncanny valley where you feel like a shadow god, but not in all the right ways. The guard AI is smart, the art direction is neat, but there's something that feels weird about accidentally jumping on top of a building and realizing that I've hit an invisible wall in a 2D game. It's not that the game is bad or that the design should be limitless, Mark of the Ninja just feels like an experience handcrafted to make me feel like a cool guy who kills a bunch of people.Metal Gear Solid 2, on the other hand, is a game that only becomes expressive after you've decided to die a bunch of times. It's linear, but the tools Kojima gives you are entirely built for survival on harder difficulties.I guess what I'm saying is that while Mark of the Ninja is a great game, it seems to miss out on the part of stealth games where you get killed a lot and are able to feel more powerful as you explore your options. It's good, though, and you should buy it!

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Great 2D platformer. Why? Animations are fluid, items are unique and allow for different solutions in each map, and the art style is very memorable. Gameplay mechanics are awesome too. For example: sound is represented as light blue circles that eventually reach the enemies, and you can use sounds to your advantage.You can sprint and jump over a guard that was previously looking away, but while you're in mid-air, he turns and you land behind him. Just doing that gives me the satisfaction of playing like a ninja. It's definitely worth your time. Rating: 9/10. It's a fantastic game. I can guarantee you won't regret buying it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												This is the first Klei game I ever played, and my GABEN was it good. Mark of the Ninja is a Stealth Platformer, and  it features a rather heavy emphasis on creatively killing your foes and hiding their bodies. Of course, since you're a ninja, you have various tools at you disposal, but your main weapon is your katana. You use it for executions (which involve pushing the control stick in one direction and pushing a button) and you can use it to finish off any foes you may have done damage to. Now, if you were stuck doing the same stuff every mission, the game would get stale, which is where new costumes come in! They can be used for everything from making executions easier, to making you an (almost) complete ghost to your enemies! This brings variety to the game, and WAY more replayability than you'd think. Oh, and did I forget to mention that this game has New Game Plus, which makes the game harder and forces you to think ahead before killing someone. Really good for people who liked Stealth ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Deluxe and other games of the sort.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												You know, as much fun as it is to run around guns blazing, mowing down wave after wave of infantry and making the world around you crumble and explode in a manner that would make Mr. Bay shed a tear... Sometimes it is nice to take a break from the braindead FPS games that flood the market to play a more mentally stimulating, slow paced stealth game. And this game certainly does it well.It amazes me that for so long I never bothered with this title, but after it came on sale, I decided to give it a try, and I admit it was worth every penny. Gameplay is challenging, there is replay value in the game due to all the gear you are given to experiment with, such as insanity darts, spike mines, choking gas and more. The story is simple at first, but starts getting more complicated as you move along, sooner or later causing you to question your actions over time. And it is it done all with beautiful 2D artwork.Sure, it can be a little frustrating at times, and sometimes it can feel cheap.. But if you work hard enough at it, it is all worth it in the end, and I like that feeling of when I manage to pull something off as I plan it.. or sometimes have something unexpected happen that makes things even better, such as driving people insane and causing them to kill each other in a panic.. Good times...Sale or not, the game certainly will keep you busy for awhile, coming not only with the normal base game but a Gameplus, which ups the challenge even further while allowing you to use all the items you unlocked along the way. Speaking of, how often do you see Gamepluses anymore?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2013
The GoodWhen I first read that this was a 2D side-scrolling stealth game, I have to admit that I scoffed at the notion and didn't really expect much of it.  But upon actually playing the game, I had to change my opinion.  It is, in point of fact, the absolute best stealth system I have ever played in any game.  Which may sound like ridiculous hyperbole, but it's absolutely true.  It's not perfect, but it may be as close as we can possibly get on this earthly plane.I have a big love-hate relationship with stealth games.  I love being able to sneak around enemies, outsmarting them, tricking them, misdirecting them.  But I hate that it's so goshdarned difficult, and my time spent playing them tends to involve a lot of swearing, save scumming, torn out hair, and thrown gamepads.  Mark of the Ninja was no exception in this, but I actually found the love part of the equation being the one in the overwhelming majority.  Even as the stakes rose ever higher and I started reloading checkpoints almost fast enough to burn a hole in my hard drive, I found myself actually relishing the challenge instead of dreading it.Aside from the absolutely stellar stealth system, there's also an excellent story of old vs. new world, loyalty and betrayal, and that regular staple of the ninja story, revenge.  The art and animation seems a little stiff in the anatomy at times, but otherwise works very well.  There is a large variety of well thought out items, abilities, achievements, and challenges to collect and complete.  And it is just so very satisfying to reach out of a ventilation grate, drag an unsuspecting guard in with you, and then end his pathetic life all in one silent, deadly, graceful move.The BadOur big bad ninja friend moves like a dream in almost every respect except that he seems a little too sticky at times, gluing himself to any and every nearby surface whether you want him too or not.  It's pretty much a necessary game mechanic, but still.  Something to watch out for.OverallI picked this game up as part of a Humble Bundle, and at the time it was just one of those other games I had to take in order to get the two or three I really wanted, but it surprised me by being the absolute best game not only in that whole batch, but one of the best games I've ever played period.  Though I sometimes try to go for 100% completion in my first playthrough of games if it's convenient, I actually went out of my way in order to get it for Mark of the Ninja.  Well, not that far out of my way, because the truth is I simply could not stop playing until it was completely done.  I ended up finishing the entire base game and then came back to Steam to buy up the Special Edition DLC and tore my way through it as well, accomplishing every single challenge and getting every single achievement before I could finally set it aside and move on to another game.I really cannot say enough good things about it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												Mark of the Ninja is a ninja simulator, plain and simple. Stealth is as much a part of it as action is, and the strongest point of the game is the way it plays with the balance between the two in order to represent a variety of different ninja tropes. The stealth works so well due to how explicit the game is. The effects of light and sound are clearly marked, leaving no guess to the consequences of your actions. This allows for complex strategies without the sudden surprise of a detection. The game's finer points are explained by a companion, Orai. This keeps tutorials and backstory in the game's context while allowing the protagonist to remain silently stoic, both avoiding an assigned protagonist personality and playing towards another ninja trope. The game's weakest areas seem to be those that weren't developed simultaneously; the cartoony art style, the same one used in the studio's previous game, doesn't quite jive with Mark of the Ninja's more serious tone and the PC control scheme leaves something to be desired. Several actions are tied to single keys based on exacting and constantly changing contexts. Despite clearly marking the outcome, this makes complicated maneuvers almost impossible to execute swiftly. As far as the DLC, the only strong point of it seems to be the commentary. It does add a new ninja path and two new weapons which do add a new set of options and restrictions, but that doesn't totally change the game. Which begs the question of whether commentary is worth the extra expense.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												I strongly recommend Mark of the Ninja!An amazing game that really focuses on stealth, and unlike every other game that claims to be about stealth--I'm looking at you, Splinter Cell--it actually delivers. There are several different styles of stealth you can choose  to play and  they're all rewarding and challenging. The level design really compliments this multi-pronged, open approach with many ways to get from A to B and back again. I found the game difficulty and pacing to be good and the simple puzzles were welcome. The dedicated puzzle trials/rooms were nice for an extra challenge. The length of the game was decent too, and I didn't collect/complete everything so that would have lengthened it a little more.I had a blast playing this, especially with the lack of real stealth games out there these days. I think old school gamers will appreciate the respect Mark of the Ninja delivers to the player, not treating them like a chump. Go, play it!

content:
Posted: January 29, 2013
												Sneaky lil platformer with loads of character, smooth gameplay and loads of fun. Playing as a Ninja just got more fun as you navigate your way around large 2D levels, hiding in the shadows, tracking enemies, infiltrating buildings and finding secrets. The option to play how you like in this game really makes it worth a look. Coupled with the visual design and the FOV/Sound mechanics, the ability to approach a heavily defended building and either sneak your way in unnoticed or butcher every guard on the way, making half of them wet themselves in fear beforehand can be incredibly satisfying. Even if your first run-through is hit-and-miss, you can go back through the levels any time and re-do them in any way you want, so you can beat your score or just mess around with new gear you unlocked in later levels, reaking revenge on those guards in earlier levels who might have spotted you the first time round. All-in-all, a definite recommend for anyone who likes a good, fun, stealth-em-up in a classic arcade style that looks and feels as good as any modern 3D game of similar genres.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												This game is basically Dishonored, if it was a 2D platformer....Okay there's a little more to it than that.In Mark of the Ninja you play as an unnamed ninja warrior, who has gained super human stealth powers from a series of mysterious tattoos he has aquired over the years, hense the title "Mark" of the Ninja.The game starts out with your Ninja training grounds being attacked my mysterious gunmen. It's up to you to track down the people responcible for the attack and annihilate them like a good ninja would. But along the way you uncover something that puts your loyalty to your Master at risk. What is it? Play it and find out.I love this game, it's one of the best stealth games I've ever played. Even though it's not an immersive first-person game, it really makes you feel like a real ninja. With how you barely make any sound when you sneak around, using the shadows to your advantage, and of course the grusome executions of enemies.One cool thing about the game is, like Dishonored, you can actually go through most levels without killing anyone. And while some may think, "Where's the fun in that?" You can actually get a bonus at the end of each level for not killing anyone, or being seen by anyone, plus going that route make the game more suspenseful and challenging.There are also some amazing weapons you aquire throughout the game. Like the "Fear Darts," which make enemies see there's fellow gunmen as horrifying hillucinations and shoot at them. Or, my favorite, the "Carnivorous Beetles" which can devour an enemy alive, bone and all.Along with the weapons, you can unlock different costumes, which each have different advantages and disadvantages. My favorite of them is definitely the "Nightmare" costume, which will instantly terrify enemies if they see someone you killed, or if they see you.The only thing I really have to complain about is that on some computers the game will run great, but right when you decide to quit the game, it will freeze your computer and you'll have to restart it. It's really annoying, but doesn't really affect the overall gameplay in any way.I really can't reccomend this game enough, even with the annoying occasional crashing at the end it's still great. If you love games like Dishonored and Assassin's Creed you'll definately love this game.

												Fantastic 2D stealth platformer.  The gameplay mechanics are original and intuitive.  The story seemed bland and unoriginal at first but I was pleasantly surprised at how it turned around near the middle and evolved into a moral dilemma for which either side could be argued.The game is a good length too; I was able to beat the main story in about 9 hours.  There's a great amount of replayability thanks to each level's goals, the extra unlockables, and the more difficult story mode replay which is unlocked after beating the main story.  I was able to manage with KB+M controls but I preferred using a controller (as is usually the case with me).Highly recommended, even at full price.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												This was a fun stealth based platformer that actually holds the threads to a very interesting story.Being a trained ninja means mystically sticking to darkness and silently skulking about.  This also is the basis of the game, no skilled point and click, instead it is a great example of a game that requires patience to execute the enemies of your clan.  You will find yourself stealthing through sewers, across city tops, and worming your way through vents as you evade the eyes and ears of your enemies and bring silent death upon them.  There are special puzzel levels hidden about but the difficulty was slightly wanting I found.The story is that of a chosen ninja, one who bears the marks that only his clan knows of, hence the title of the game.  The marks will imbue you with power beyond any mortal, but there is a price to pay.  The legend tells of those that undergo the ink will do the will of the clan and then must turn their sword upon themselves or else bring ruin on their clan.  This story element really comes to fruition at the very end and was wonderfully put forward by the creators.  The story also comes alive with the fun and stylized are found through the game.I would recomend the this game for those who have patience for stealth, and for everyone if it is on sale.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												An excelent example of good concept and amazing execution.The clear mechanics and difficulty based on studying patterns, utilizing tools and spotting opportunities are all very important parts of a good stealth game and Mark of the Ninja pulled them all off damn near flawlessly as well as integrating fun puzzles, a well balanced system of progression for RPG suckers like myself, hidden level stuff for completitionists, granting great replayability AND having an awesome art style. If I was to estimate the amount of time it would take to ace the game (and NG+), I'd prolly say below 40 hours.The only "negative" thing about this game is that I ended up wanting more of it after beating NG+, though I'm definitely not saying that the game didn't give enough to begin with.

But by far the best way to do things seems to be by the use of fear.All in all it is unbelievable that I always felt the challenge and no frustration.I can really recommend this game and also his DLC, which adds some new features and commentary from the whole programmers team.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												To start: I used to add a header to these reviews, but since it often made the review too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery page.Gameplay: I never really was all that great at the Stealth genre, given my very guns-a-blazing kind of playstyle. Nevertheless, I usually have a lot of fun with the games. Mark of the Ninja is one of the most fun stealth games that I've played in a long time, as well as being one of the most immersive. The reason why is because of the stage design. Stages are absolute monsters that sometimes feel like a Super Metroid level than anything else. This game has a lot of exploration capabilities as well as plenty of non-linear apporaches you can take to meet objectives. There's even plenty of items to suit your playstyle. Do you wanna have fun scaring the pants off of enemies? String up bodies on grapple points. Are you a fan of the "out of sight, out of mind" mentality of guard AI? There's a suit that allows you to have full motion silence with the tradeoff of not being able to bring a sword with you. I'm more of a fan of going undetected and (preferably) not killing anyone, as I feel that stays truest to the stealth genre as a whole. However, if combat becomes a necessity, you could always hack your way out of a scenario.While I hardly did any fighting myself, the enemies seem to have pretty good AI whenever they've caught a glance at you, often backing up for reinforcements then pushing hard. There's also enough enemy variety to keep things interesting, but most of the time the thing that makes the game interesting are the stages themselves. Usually I get a bit annoyed whenever a game doesn't have any boss fights, but I wasn't that annoyed with it in this game, as an actual boss would've felt counter-intuitive to the design of the game. As far as the challenge of this game, I could see this being pretty easy for the stealth savant, but for the average person, I think the difficulty is just about right, if a bit too easy at the beginning. I think that the game could've done with a few less checkpoints per area so that you really have to slow down and not make things a trial and error fest, but I could also see the reasoning for the checkpoints. Checkpoints can screw you over at times, although this only happened to me once (a checkpoint put me in front of an enemy, ruining my chances for a no detect for that level), so be sure to take it easy for a couple of seconds once you see the checkpoint symbol.Apart from that, there really isn't too much more to talk about. It's a stealth game with a ton of great design sensibilities, it allows you to take things however you want to, and it's overall just a really fun game that's definitely worth your time. 10/10.Story: Everything up to the ending: pretty not bad, but not anything terribly memorable. The ending: should not be as good as it was. No seriously, dat ending. Actually, in retrospect, one of the main purposes of the plot up until the ending seems to be setting seeds for the final areas. As for the characters, they're kind of prototypical Japanese ninja movie characters, but oh well. Dat ending. 8/10.Graphics: I don't need to tell you that this game is absolutely phenomenal looking. You've got eyes. As for the technical aspects, the game fullscreened to my native resolution of 1080p without any hassle. Also, if you do happen to skip cutscenes, you may find that areas lag for a bit but then sort themselves out afterward. It's only a minor annoyance, since once you get past those spots, the game runs at a perfect 60FPS. 5/5.Sound: The soundtrack is pretty dang good, and once again, the ending is the thing that really takes the cake. Most of it is pretty ambient stuff, but it does a very good job at setting the mood. Fortunately, there weren't any sound glitches I experienced. As for the voice acting, it works fine. It's good enough. No award winning material, but hey, we can't expect that from everything. Disappointingly, it doesn't seem like the Special Edition comes with the soundtrack, but oh well; that's what Youtube is for. 5/5.Overall scores are: 10/8/5/5; cumulative score of 9.3/10. I noticed that this review ended up being a lot shorter than a lot of my others. Honestly, I think that's because I don't really have anything else to say other than, "It's good. You should go get it."

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Mark of the Ninja is one of the best stealth games, one of the best platformers, and one of the best ninja games in recent years.  With a gameplay style that rewards tactical precision while still keeping a brisk pace, the game manages to work your brain and reflexes in a way that feels exciting and familiar as a player.  The story is clichéd but sincere, the levels are more videogame than reality, and sometimes you'll encounter a loophole or exploit to take away your immersion in favor of ratcheting up your score, but you'll enjoy every minute of it.  Every challenge is met with enjoyment.  No part of the game ever feels like it drags or has that "boring act" structure.The gameplay is finely tuned, with inspiration from every major stealth title out there put to good use.  Nothing is wasted; everything is fun.  There's little higher praise than that.And it has the best type of New Game + mode, where the fundamental mechanics are altered significantly for a heightened challenge.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												Pretty Good Game Review Considering (PGGRC) 6.1 Hours to Complete TL;DR - YES I DO RECOMMEND THIS AMAZING AND SURPIRSE OF A GAME. Wow never has a 2D game been so strategic. When the stealth mechanics work so fluent, slick and has more stealth mechanics of other games but way less of the budget you know you have a great dev that understands what games are about.In depth:Performance - Its 2D and runs on almost anything. Graphics - Even though it run on almost everything doesn’t think this game is a pig. This game is a beauty. Not only from the beautiful Japanese’s inspired art style but from the landscapes and even character design. Gameplay - It’s quite a short game (depending on playstyles, I’ll get too that in a bit :) and quite easy (if you don’t care about score or challenges). If you don’t care about challenges then you won’t be able to upgrade your gear which you will need. Every gadget and clothing has a purpose and is different from one another and actually offers a different playstyle. Whether you pick the stealth armour, allowing moving silently and holding more non-lethal gadgets or an amour that makes you feel like a juggernaugh allowing you to rip people apart or even armour allowing you to teleport to completely leave the enemies untouched. Needed more enemy design also to vary up engagements. Ending needed to be better if the story was compelling or if each ending showed the aftermath of each choice, it would actually be worth it but the payoff lacked as pacing and depth was non-existent. Just note that the "DLC" MISSION NOT STORY IS AWFUL. Lasts TEN MINIUTES FOR ♥♥♥♥ SAKE and lacks any different content aside from few gear and costume you can use in the main game. Very disappointing.Replayability - For all unlocks, two endings (not worth replaying it for to be honest as story is weak sauce) and different playstyles as well as how fun it is, yes it’s worth it. Conclusion - This game offers a lot for a low price. Has more depth in stealth mechanics than assassin’s creed for crying out loud. Fun, fluent and varied. The game looks and feels beautiful and if the story had build up and character it would be a perfect game.If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow my curator group: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/FALLENV3GAS#curation

content:
Posted: February 12, 2013
												Mark of the Ninja is a slick and stylish stealth action platformer.You infiltrate and assassinate your way through 12 gorgeously designed levels. The art is beautiful and the animations are slick. There is a range of environments, each with stunning vibrant parallax scrolling backgrounds offsetting the generally monochrome foreground.You start out with a relatively simple set of moves, introducing you to how stealth works in the game; Enemies have vision cones, moving quickly makes sound which draws enemies, you can hide behind environmental objects like vases and dumpsters, slipping through vents and setting up ambushes.The game slowly increases your equipment and move set (all of which can be customised) as you play. Each level has challenges for you to attempt, each of which unlocks a token you can spend on upgrading your gear. Complete enough of certain challenge types will unlock new costumes which include a gear restriction or boon. For example, completing 3 'Terror' challenges unlocks a gear set that makes you run without making any noise, but you lose your sword, forcing you to a fast and non-lethal playstyle.The story is relatively simplistic, but presented in short stylized cutscenes that work well. The story has a twist with a choice at the end, but it is nothing earth-shattering and not really the focus of the experience. The joy here is in the gameplay, the smooth controls (even if playing with a keyboard and mouse) and the art.After completion you unlock a new game plus mode, which increases the number of guards and increases the difficulty.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												This game was great, I never really liked stealth that much in games, not disliked, just prefered other playstyles, so when Mark of the Ninja came up on steam sale I was unsure however the other glowing reviews swayed it. The cartoon style immediately put me off; how can you have a serious stealth game when it looks like a childrens program? But after the first bloody kill I was won over. The cartoon style works, it may not be your favorite but you'll soon get over it with gameplay as engaging as this is, however you want to play the game you will find it rewarding. Whether you wish to leap over heads not hurting a fly or wish to leave a trail of death and destruction in you're wake the game gives you points which in turn can be used to unlock various things; either equipment or abilities. That is another aspect of the game I love, the upgrades, while none of them completely change your character you can use various combinations to result in a very different playing experience. The story isn't brilliant but heck you can't expect them to get everything right! GIve this game a go, I promise you won't be disapointed

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												I could not have asked for a better ninja game. Everything about this game screams terrific design. It captures the spirit of true ninjutsu: complete nothingness and silence, alongside the occasional assassination. The path you take as a ninja is completely up to you, ranging from a murderous nightmare towards every guard to an undetectable ghost. The game is more than happy to give you various options in approaching every situation. I was also pleased by how varied the levels are; one time you will be infiltrating a fortress, the next time you'll be escaping poison-filled catacombs, and another time you will be setting a building on fire. I also found the game to be quite challenging and as of writing this review have yet to earn all the achievements...and complete a harder New Game+.The art direction is fantastic, harkening me back to the style of Batman: The Animated Series, Star Wars: Clone Wars, and Samurai Jack. Plus, the visual cues regarding sound and light is nothing short of genius.The story is surprisingly intriguing and the end led to much reflection of my playthrough as a ninja. The characters are good with well-executed voice-acting. Overall, very well-written.With all this being said, this is a ninja game. What more could you want? 10/10

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												An all around excellent stealth game. The two demensional nature of this game makes it quite different from most games I play, but doesn't feel restricted at all. You can play through the game using a myriad of different strategies from killing everyone stealthily, killing everyone and not caring if you get caught, or going the whole game without killing anyone or even letting them see you. No matter what style you prefer in each level, you will feel like a total bad♥♥♥♥♥jumping, sneaking, and slaughtering through levels.Each new level introduces something new whether it be new kinds of challenges, enemies, or new tools to solve challenges. You can unlock new types of stealth kills as you go as well as new items and outfits with different perks and drawbacks. So there was no chance of me getting bored on my first playthrough. And replay value is great because you can try out different styles of play or pick up achievments/unlock new things if you missed aything the first time. For example, I played through the entire game on the harder dificulty mode without killing anyone after playing through the game as a bad♥♥♥♥♥assassin first.The plot is also suprisingly detailed and nuanced and keeps you guessing who your real enemies are.10/10 - a very innexpensive game to pick up to try out, and I would be willing to pay even more.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												Arguably the best side scroller game I have played to date, this game has it all.  From a fantastic story shown through cutscene that remind me fondly of Outlaws to open ended stealth play where you can vary your approach to enemies and certain puzzles based on the style you wish.  Controls are tight (for the most part), graphics are near perfect in style and mood, and level design (while tad repetitive) is good with jumping puzzles being kept in check.Overall the game kept me engaged throughout and the list of achievements to attempt are thoughtful and challengingly fun.  If you are looking for a stellar 2D sidescroller that harkens back to oldies like Blackthorne and combines it with splashes of Deus Ex and the style of Shank then look no further.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2013
												10/10I held off on getting and then playing this game for a long time (I absolutely detest Shank 2). How wrong I was!I fell totally in love with it. Controls are ideal, levels are designed to give you multiple options for objective completion. There are usually alternate paths to avoid or take out guards in different ways, for example. The scoring/leaderboard system encourages you to replay levels and beat your record. If you're good at the game and know what to expect in a level, you can really fly through - but each level can also take quite a long time, especially if you're looking for the secrets (and want to unlock all the goodies - different stealth moves and weapons!). I think player progression is key in making a great game - ask yourself if you become a better player as you progress through the game. If not, then it's mostly just a time sink. If yes, then the rewards are much greater! In Mark of the Ninja, the answer is a resounding yes, a testament to how polished and well-designed the game is.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												This is an outstanding little game. The art style is terrific. The game looks unique and visually appealing. Though more sophisticated, the look has elements reminiscent of Samurai Jack (epic cartoon by the way). The biggest draw for me was that you are a ninja, you get to sneak around wielding the mighty sword of Tetsuji a while doing stealth kills that are brutal and awesome (childhood fantasy fulfilled).The level design is excellent, the puzzles are clever and challenging but not so punishing that you’ll get frustrated. A big plus is that when you do fail, the game reloads almost immediately so you can try again, a little wiser with each death. So many games drag out your death, or you have to wait an eternity for them to reload, it just makes you ram your head into your monitor.Finally, the game does an excellent job of telling a good story. The levels are immersive and have great atmosphere, the characters are developed well enough for you to become attached to them and they balance the narrative so you can appreciate both sides.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2013
												The graphics are presented in a cartoonish 2D style enviroment with smooth visuals that are very easy on the eyes, despite the constant dark tones. Makes a very nice change from the 8-bit style Indie developers are obsessed about. The animations are well drawn & silky smooth, really bringing life to the game. Watching guards move around with momentum makes them feel more like actual game characters rather than 2D sprites. The death animations are equally as satisfying, if not more so.The game levels are large & leave alot of choice to the player. You can murder every single guard in the game, or use your Ninja tools to slip past without killing a single soul, plus able to turn your enemies against each other, terrifying them into friendly fire incidents. There are multiple pathways throughout each area too. Maybe you want to grapple hook & jump along the rooftops. Or maybe you want to scurry down below in the sewers. It's not often a game gives you such open ended approaches, Think Deus Ex & Dishonored. This is absolutely brilliant!!! Killing enemies itself is quite fun & challenging. You can sneak through an air duct & come across a guard walking above a grate, & you can snatch him through the grate to kill him whilst at the same time hiding his body. Or there can be 2 guards: 1 smoking under a ridge & another patrolling. When the patrolling one is not looking, you can pull a chain round the smoker's neck & yank him up & leave his dead body hanging, & watch the other guard fall over in horror when he sees his former friend hanged from the ceiling, illuminated by a strike of lightening (which is sadistically hilarious to watch).There are some character skills & unlockable upgrades, earned by performing optional challenges in each mission. More killing techniques are always welcome, as well as enhancing your distraction tools and weapons. A few costumes can be unlocked, each with their own perks, such as make no noise when running, but unable to carry a sword. It's a blast to replay a previous level & use new abilities to discover alternate ways to complete the level or reach hidden areas.So while the game is very good, there are some negative points. The controls seriously need alot of work. Buttons conflict with each other: one button is used for both hiding yourself & carrying bodies, & another button used for interaction, jumping & climbing. This leads to situations where there's a body next to a hiding spot, & you want to hide but end up dragging the body & getting shot to death as a result, or wanting to climb around a corner of a ceiling, but end up jumping off into the path of a deadly laser. Why couldn't they have borrowed the idea from Assassins Creed where a button modifies the characters interactions? I'm pretty sure that left bumper on the gamepad is unused by this game.      The controls work most of the time, it's moments like these that lead to frustration. Oh yea & it would be nice if moving the camera lets you choose specific targets instead of having to use the movement keys to do so, it doesn't make sense otherwise. This leads to the character moving in order to target enemies, possibly moving too much & either losing sight of the target or getting spotted as a result.     They did try to vary the enviroment a fair bit, unfortunately later levels start to suffer, particularly the platforming one, a level with sandstorms with explosive mines, & the ones taking place in caves which don't offer much freedom of movement.     While not a major issue, it would be nice to see a bit more varied animations. There seems to be only 2 death animations for each kill type & some of them seem to play rarely. The animations are so good in this game that I'd like to see more! To wrap things up, this game is an absolute must have!! It's stealth mechanics are both appealing to hardcore & casual players, the visuals are very pleasing, there's tons of replayability, as well as encouraging you to use different playstyles. Being a Ninja has never been so much fun!

content:

												Mark of the Ninja is an awesome game. Controlling the ninja with keyboard and mouse at first feels uncomfortable, but I got used to it really fast. There may be times when you have to act real quick and you mess it up, but I always could do the things I want to do and I never had a problem with controls.The challenges in the game are great as well. You probably can skip them, if they are too hard for you, but you'll miss 70% of the games content.I really like the possibility that you can just kill everybody head-on and get away with it, if you are fast enough. Or you can sneak all around, be never seen and (almost) kill nobody in the entire game. But by far the best way to do things seems to be by the use of fear.All in all it is unbelievable that I always felt the challenge and no frustration.I can really recommend this game and also his DLC, which adds some new features and commentary from the whole programmers team.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												Another good pitch for my favourate game. Mark of the Ninja shows how to do stealth games properly. Your visable or your not, they can hear you or they can't. All expressed by the visual and artistic choices of the development team. Rings of sound raidiate from you or objects in the real world, ring crosses an enemy before it dissipates, too bad. Enemies can enter carying states, if one finds a corpse you so delicatly dangled from that pipe?  Now he is ♥♥♥♥ing terrified. Time-outs for being spotted barely last 10s, kill the person who spotted you before he raises the alarm. Panic over. Kill him after? Well others are still coming, sprint and they will hear you, hide who knows if they will find you and stay to meet a prompt death. Waiting is fun in this game, the 2D visuals make it "clear" every alternative path (not counting secret areas) and while your hiding away from the flashlights and drama, you have a moment to re-evaluate the route and see the new enemy positions. At the end you face a dilema. You do things by mistake, thing's you cannot fix. Will you continue on, as you did from moment one after your moment of truth or will you make a sacrifice.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2016
												Mark of the Ninja is the best stealth game since Thief 1/2. If you want a stealth game, you won't find a better one. Unlike the Thief games, MotN plays in 2D; however the transition from 3D to 2D doesn't mean it's less complex than the Thief games. You'll still have to be careful not to be seen, not to make too much noise and there are many side objectives in every level to keep things interesting.All gameplay systems come together perfectly in the best stealth game in recent times. It's so good that I 100%ed it - MoTn is the first Steam game where I've completed every achievement and I've done everything there is to be done (it took me ~20 hours including the DLC level, so there's good value for your money). Besides GOAT tier gameplay, MotN also offers a simple but powerful story that complements the gameplay perfectly. Graphics are nice, consisting of cartoon like sprites which are superbly animated. Sounds are deeply connected to the game's stealth system and are well implemented. And the level design is amazing. Seriously. Every level is built in such way to make you feel like the most badass ninja to ever exist (which in the context of the game, you are). Kudos to the level designer. There are also unlockables that you earn after each level/side objective. And after you complete the main campaign there's also a New Game+ mode, for that 'no kill run' you'll want to do.When I was a kid, I used to play a lot on my ZX Spectrum and one of my favourite games was Saboteur, a game that made me feel like a ninja. ~30 years later, MotN reminded me of Saboteur, not from a gameplay pov but because it gave me the same "omg amazing best game ever" feel. All in all, I have no bad things to say about this game. If you want to feel like a ninja, try MotN. If you want to play the best stealth game since the original Thief games, play MotN. It's truly a must play.

content:

												This game reminds me of the old Splinter Cell.Gameplay-10/10  Stealth mechanics are solid and as you complete objectives you learn new methods to assassinate your opponents. I enjoyed solving the puzzles and listening to the narrated poems helped immerse me into the setting.Overall Experience-8/10 A must play if you like the old Splinter Cell.If you want to take your enemies head on, you might want to play Samurai Showdown or CoD; because ninjas primarily focus on stealth and traps to take out their enemies.Update 11/28/2016: Still a great game!

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												This is indeed the first game that I have successfully played through on steam and I must say I am very very impressed with pretty much everything it had to offer. Though I must probaby add that I have only just completed the normal game mode. And, boy, was that an awesome experience.It offers amazing visual and sound effects actually helping you on your way through, which also create the majestic piece of art that this game is. The levels get gradually harder (although not too hard) and you gain more skills/items as you go. The different puzzles you have to solve make for an exciting brain tease with a rewarding "YES"-effect after you've managed to trick those pesky guards. The story (if you decide to read through and follow mentally) is rather thrilling and you really feel involved into the actual outcome.I have played it with a controller and it did feel surprisingly easy to manouver and execute any sneaky action I attempted. I have also loved the tooltips about all the aspects of the creation of the game. It really gives the player a relatively good insight in what it takes to create certain aspects of the game.Overall an impressive game that actually brings what it takes to be an assassin. If you are looking for THE assassin game out there right now, I'd point you in this direction.Personal rating 10/10. I really can't find any bad aspect about the game right now, except for it lacking a second part, which I am suspecting will come out at some point (haven't checked yet)

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												I'd recommend this game on sale to anyone, but its particularly fans of stealth as long as you don't expect RPG-type depth. The mechanics for noise, starting in the darkness, and out of the light are all very polished, as shown in the written dev commentary that can optionally be enabled in the Special Edition.  This 2D game manages to be one of the best stealth/ninja games I've ever heard of.My playstyle was divided fairly evenly between stealth and killing. What kept me from going full stealth was that there were so many special physical abilities giving unique circumstances to kill people. There are also many distraction & weapon type items too, whether leathal or non-lethal.  To balance killing vs stealth though, end of level scoring seems to favor stealth.  However, it is possible to achieve the highest per level scoring tiers as long as you do more unique environmental kills, body hiding, or trigger friendly fire.  Perhaps the only downside to the game is that I've unlocked enough on my first playthrough that I'm not sure I want to play through again on the Plus difficulty.  The Plus difficulty was great for the one expansion level, and definitely makes it much harder to do a stealth only run.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2013
												I've been a fan of Stealth games for a long time, as far back as the original Metal Gear games for the NES. This is by far one of the best executed and most fun stealth games that I've ever played. It shares a distinction with Dishonored as one of the only two stealth games (or games in general) that I've ever enjoyed enough to play through again immediately after finishing it. Whereas in general I find Achievements as nothing I'm overly interested in, they totally work in this game because you want to see if you can pull off all of the things that there are achievements for.Additionally, as you play through you earn points that allow you to unlock extra ninja tools, suits and upgrades. This also provides a great impetus to play through levels trying to hone your skills in order to unlock everything. Following that you immediately want to go back through previous levels and play through them with the new equipment as well.I will say that this game was the one that caused me to purchase an XBox controller for my PC just to play it. It seemed to work OK with keyboard and mouse controls, but something about it (perhaps just my old school gamer-ness) makes it much easier and much more satisfying with a proper controller.In all this game is just incredibly spot-on, well polished and well executed. I can't recommend it highly enough.

content:

												I strongly recommend Mark of the Ninja!An amazing game that really focuses on stealth, and unlike every other game that claims to be about stealth--I'm looking at you, Splinter Cell--it actually delivers. There are several different styles of stealth you can choose  to play and  they're all rewarding and challenging. The level design really compliments this multi-pronged, open approach with many ways to get from A to B and back again. I found the game difficulty and pacing to be good and the simple puzzles were welcome. The dedicated puzzle trials/rooms were nice for an extra challenge. The length of the game was decent too, and I didn't collect/complete everything so that would have lengthened it a little more.I had a blast playing this, especially with the lack of real stealth games out there these days. I think old school gamers will appreciate the respect Mark of the Ninja delivers to the player, not treating them like a chump. Go, play it!

												Finally a game that does stealth right,and it's an indie!Mark of the Ninja is a game that will entertain you for sure!It has a powerful theme,fun mechanics and interesting art style.It really makes you feel like a ninja and it does not mess up the gameplay because of the stealth mechanics.You will have to make a lot of choices because the game lets you finish a level in a multitude of ways.You have a big arsenal of ninja/stealth weapons and accessories which add up to the replay-abiltiy of the game.You can choose the accessories that fit your style of play or you can mess around and have some fun!You can either go on a rampage and kill everyone or be as stealthy as you can and leave no trace.It gives you the choice and it's awesome!The storyline is also quite good with beautifully done cinematics in-between.Again I would like to say that the gameplay is incredibly well done and it really feels like a stealth game even if it's a 2-D game.I highly recommend this game even for people that do not like stealth games.It's something else..it's unique and you should try it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2013
												TL;DR Really fun side-scrolling stealth game, if a little short. Ending makes you think. Definitely try it.I really enjoyed this game. It's a side-scrolling stealth game with an art style that really makes me think of Samurai Jack. The gameplay is really gun and fairly challenging at times. The controls are really good, and hardly ever caused an issue besides once or twice where I stuck to the wrong wall, but that was likely my fault. The controls are so good enough that you never feel cheated when you die, it's always your fault.The story doesn't seem like much until you get close to the end, where there's a twist and then everything starts to make sense. The ending itself left me felt a little unfulfilled, but I think it's made to make you fill in the blanks yourself. It really gets you thinking about your choice, why you did what you did, but doesn't tell you what happens next, so how good the conclusion to this game really is what you make of it.I only got 7 hours out of this game, so I felt like it could have been longer, although I did skip a lot of the side missions, and I do feel like much of the challenge comes from the challenges you set yourself (Don't raise any alarms, never get seen, don't kill anyone, etc). but besides that I can't really think of anything that was wrong with this game.I'm not sure what else I can say about this game, but if you enjoy stealth games, this one is great fun, and worth the money. If the store page looks good, get it, otherwise try it when it's a bit cheaper.8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												You know, as much fun as it is to run around guns blazing, mowing down wave after wave of infantry and making the world around you crumble and explode in a manner that would make Mr. Bay shed a tear... Sometimes it is nice to take a break from the braindead FPS games that flood the market to play a more mentally stimulating, slow paced stealth game. And this game certainly does it well.It amazes me that for so long I never bothered with this title, but after it came on sale, I decided to give it a try, and I admit it was worth every penny. Gameplay is challenging, there is replay value in the game due to all the gear you are given to experiment with, such as insanity darts, spike mines, choking gas and more. The story is simple at first, but starts getting more complicated as you move along, sooner or later causing you to question your actions over time. And it is it done all with beautiful 2D artwork.Sure, it can be a little frustrating at times, and sometimes it can feel cheap.. But if you work hard enough at it, it is all worth it in the end, and I like that feeling of when I manage to pull something off as I plan it.. or sometimes have something unexpected happen that makes things even better, such as driving people insane and causing them to kill each other in a panic.. Good times...Sale or not, the game certainly will keep you busy for awhile, coming not only with the normal base game but a Gameplus, which ups the challenge even further while allowing you to use all the items you unlocked along the way. Speaking of, how often do you see Gamepluses anymore?

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												An all around excellent stealth game. The two demensional nature of this game makes it quite different from most games I play, but doesn't feel restricted at all. You can play through the game using a myriad of different strategies from killing everyone stealthily, killing everyone and not caring if you get caught, or going the whole game without killing anyone or even letting them see you. No matter what style you prefer in each level, you will feel like a total bad♥♥♥♥♥jumping, sneaking, and slaughtering through levels.Each new level introduces something new whether it be new kinds of challenges, enemies, or new tools to solve challenges. You can unlock new types of stealth kills as you go as well as new items and outfits with different perks and drawbacks. So there was no chance of me getting bored on my first playthrough. And replay value is great because you can try out different styles of play or pick up achievments/unlock new things if you missed aything the first time. For example, I played through the entire game on the harder dificulty mode without killing anyone after playing through the game as a bad♥♥♥♥♥assassin first.The plot is also suprisingly detailed and nuanced and keeps you guessing who your real enemies are.10/10 - a very innexpensive game to pick up to try out, and I would be willing to pay even more.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2012
												Earlier this year I said that FTL would likely go down as my favorite indie game of 2012, however I didn't expect Mark of the Ninja to come along. I wasn't even fully sure if MotN was indie, due to the polish and depth of content. I have played many titles from big-name developers that weren't even close to this level of competency. Enough rambling, on to the game... The gameplay is somewhere between Thief: The Dark Project and 16-bit side scrollers of the 90s. There is a bit of trial and error, but it's rarely frustrating and victory always feels rewarding. Nevermind the fact that there is almost always a number of solutions to each problem, the game was never repetitive enough to get boring, even after beating it twice for all of the achievements. Very few games balance repetition and play time so well. In addition, the interesting art style (very much Penny Arcade inspired) with tight controls and decent plot make this a solid must buy for anyone that likes stealth or side scrolling combat games.

												A stunning game that captures the best 2-Dimensional stealth I've ever seen.  All throughout my playtime I can honestly say I felt like a ninja. While there is a New Game+ mode that offers a bit more challenge, it's still the same missions that you've already played through, so there isn't much that will surprise you your second time around.  It's an awesome game that, in my opinion, definitely needs a sequel.  And the sequel needs a level creator and Steam Workshop!  Gameplay is incredible and smooth, but the amount of gameplay truly available is certainly a downfall.  Definitely still a recommended playthrough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												This was a fun stealth based platformer that actually holds the threads to a very interesting story.Being a trained ninja means mystically sticking to darkness and silently skulking about.  This also is the basis of the game, no skilled point and click, instead it is a great example of a game that requires patience to execute the enemies of your clan.  You will find yourself stealthing through sewers, across city tops, and worming your way through vents as you evade the eyes and ears of your enemies and bring silent death upon them.  There are special puzzel levels hidden about but the difficulty was slightly wanting I found.The story is that of a chosen ninja, one who bears the marks that only his clan knows of, hence the title of the game.  The marks will imbue you with power beyond any mortal, but there is a price to pay.  The legend tells of those that undergo the ink will do the will of the clan and then must turn their sword upon themselves or else bring ruin on their clan.  This story element really comes to fruition at the very end and was wonderfully put forward by the creators.  The story also comes alive with the fun and stylized are found through the game.I would recomend the this game for those who have patience for stealth, and for everyone if it is on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												An excelent example of good concept and amazing execution.The clear mechanics and difficulty based on studying patterns, utilizing tools and spotting opportunities are all very important parts of a good stealth game and Mark of the Ninja pulled them all off damn near flawlessly as well as integrating fun puzzles, a well balanced system of progression for RPG suckers like myself, hidden level stuff for completitionists, granting great replayability AND having an awesome art style. If I was to estimate the amount of time it would take to ace the game (and NG+), I'd prolly say below 40 hours.The only "negative" thing about this game is that I ended up wanting more of it after beating NG+, though I'm definitely not saying that the game didn't give enough to begin with.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												"The best stealth game ever made?"Not sure about that. I would still give this title to Thief 2. That said, Klei seems to have a talent of creating brilliant games no matter what genre they reach for and MoN is no different.Great artstyle mixing western-style animation and Japanese themes. This 2d stealth game allowing for variety of approaches. You want to sneak? You can. You want to murder everyone in the room? You can. You want to murder one guard and hung him high to terrify other guards, who the fall to their deaths, or shoot other guards. You can. While levels aren't complex as in earlier mentioned original Thief games or Hitman: Blood Money, they are designed well enough to allow for different paths and encourage exploration. Add to that really solid game mechanics which allow you to make your own path if you feel like it, by distracting enemies or taking out guards in ways not specifficaly designed by creators. The UI makes sure that whatever you do you know hom much noise you make and who and how can hear you.  Thanks to this you always know how much noise you make and can plan your moves accordingly.Anything bad? The writing could be better. While the story is pretty solid and the little "Haiku scrolls" you find in every level are brilliant, I am not a big fan of the dialogue in the game. It is just too dry and character-less. Still, a must buy for anyone even remotely interested in stealth games.

												one of the best stealth games i've played, and 'till now, the best title from klei (haven't played invisible inc. that much tho). the graphics are stylish, the plot is simple but it's thrilling and it makes you want to continue playing until it is finished, the gameplay allows for multiple approaches, you can just kill the ♥♥♥♥ out of everyone or get past silently, ant the difficulty... well, that is a hard point to discuss. The difficulty itself is kinda hard, but the checkpoint system is too forgiving, it saves before and aftes any major encounter, but you are going to fail. multiple times. you'll hit that restart checkpoint button so many times (if you wanna get it right, tho. as i said before you can ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥up, keep running straight and boom, you finish the level, but that's not the way it's meant to be played, so if you wanna embrace the experience of the ninja, you gotta play it right, and it's hard) you'll kiss the developers♥♥♥♥♥for those recurring checkpoints. that being said, it's not a hard game because of the checkpoints, but if you try and play without them, you're pretty much ♥♥♥♥ed.I recommend it strongly, get it right now.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												A stylized 2D take on the stealth genre. Overlooked this game for a while but really glad I picked it up. The game has a decent sized campaign with lots of challenges in every level. I found there was a lot of ways to approach every situation, either with lethal or non lethal takedowns, entry points or use of gadgets. Really felt like a true badass ninja in this game. You have the ability to terrorize your enemies and sink back into the shadows, causing them to panic and attack other guards, it's pretty great. I felt like Batman. Like I said very nicely stylized, which I expected from a Klei game. Nice art direction and animations all around, and cool tradition ninja themes mixed with more high-tech stuff. Still think I'm going to play this more to complete more challenges and play with different loadouts and ninja suits. If you're into stealth or sidescrollers I'd say pick this up!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												This game was all I expected it to be, and more ! I read some reviews and knew it was a nervous infiltration ninja game. I also knew the story wasn't so bad and the art pretty cool. All of this was true, and more. The game was super fun to play, the levels are deep and engaging, it rewards exploration and trying to navigate your ways out of all the danger is always possible, but makes you think a lot. The best part was that if you think and try to act like a true ninja, it might work, even in your first run. Being cautious is rewarded, but acting and thinking quickly also. Only flaw might be that killing guards and other ennemies is highly encouraged, storywise it makes perfect sense, you get points for it and hidding the bodies too. You get a no kill bonus at the end of the stage if you successfully kill no one, but it's much more fun and if you kill 10 ennemies properly, you get more points at the end anyway. So that's the only flaw, not too bad I guess. You unlock super cool new skins that grants you new powers and really change the flow of your gameplay. For instance, the tatoo skin lets you teleport nightcrawler like, and it's so cool !!! Another one lets you run without making any sounds and gives you more gadgets, but you can't kill anyone anymore, so this is the best way to get those smooth runs you're looking for. The art is perfect, think samurai jack but better looking. The story really got me hooked, and the ending is simply perfect. It's a short game, you'll see the end in 10 hours, but to unlock everything might take some more of your time. In conclusion, Mark of the Ninja is exactly what it sets out to be, a fun, fast paced infiltration game with a great aesthetic, and more !

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												A great chemistry between traditionally different elements and a big love letter to those who enjoy fluid side-scrollers and the stealth genre. The graphics are simple yet effective. Animations are smooth, non-redundant and tastefully exaggerated. Controls are incredibly compact, which will certainly help you stay in function in every single move. This is absolutely important in an action-stealth game.Gameplay in Mark of the Ninja is highly innovative, and also very brutal. You as a ninja are given a wide variety of equipment, tools and courses of actions to proceed and complete your missions. However, make one wrong move, and you may consider yourself finished, as you are a Ninja, not a Rambo. The shadow is your friend, not the fists.Overall, Mark of the Ninja is an absolute gem of the 2D side-scroller and stealth genre. If you are a big fan of either of those, or both, then this game is definitely a must-have.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2013
												10/10I held off on getting and then playing this game for a long time (I absolutely detest Shank 2). How wrong I was!I fell totally in love with it. Controls are ideal, levels are designed to give you multiple options for objective completion. There are usually alternate paths to avoid or take out guards in different ways, for example. The scoring/leaderboard system encourages you to replay levels and beat your record. If you're good at the game and know what to expect in a level, you can really fly through - but each level can also take quite a long time, especially if you're looking for the secrets (and want to unlock all the goodies - different stealth moves and weapons!). I think player progression is key in making a great game - ask yourself if you become a better player as you progress through the game. If not, then it's mostly just a time sink. If yes, then the rewards are much greater! In Mark of the Ninja, the answer is a resounding yes, a testament to how polished and well-designed the game is.

												I don't remember the last time I was so taken by a 2D game. But by this I sure was, maybe it's even the best 2D game I ever played. The story is a weaker ninja story, but you don't play games like this for the story. The biggest plus is the clever stealth with the use of various gadgets. content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Fantastic 2D stealth platformer.  The gameplay mechanics are original and intuitive.  The story seemed bland and unoriginal at first but I was pleasantly surprised at how it turned around near the middle and evolved into a moral dilemma for which either side could be argued.The game is a good length too; I was able to beat the main story in about 9 hours.  There's a great amount of replayability thanks to each level's goals, the extra unlockables, and the more difficult story mode replay which is unlocked after beating the main story.  I was able to manage with KB+M controls but I preferred using a controller (as is usually the case with me).Highly recommended, even at full price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2013
The GoodWhen I first read that this was a 2D side-scrolling stealth game, I have to admit that I scoffed at the notion and didn't really expect much of it.  But upon actually playing the game, I had to change my opinion.  It is, in point of fact, the absolute best stealth system I have ever played in any game.  Which may sound like ridiculous hyperbole, but it's absolutely true.  It's not perfect, but it may be as close as we can possibly get on this earthly plane.I have a big love-hate relationship with stealth games.  I love being able to sneak around enemies, outsmarting them, tricking them, misdirecting them.  But I hate that it's so goshdarned difficult, and my time spent playing them tends to involve a lot of swearing, save scumming, torn out hair, and thrown gamepads.  Mark of the Ninja was no exception in this, but I actually found the love part of the equation being the one in the overwhelming majority.  Even as the stakes rose ever higher and I started reloading checkpoints almost fast enough to burn a hole in my hard drive, I found myself actually relishing the challenge instead of dreading it.Aside from the absolutely stellar stealth system, there's also an excellent story of old vs. new world, loyalty and betrayal, and that regular staple of the ninja story, revenge.  The art and animation seems a little stiff in the anatomy at times, but otherwise works very well.  There is a large variety of well thought out items, abilities, achievements, and challenges to collect and complete.  And it is just so very satisfying to reach out of a ventilation grate, drag an unsuspecting guard in with you, and then end his pathetic life all in one silent, deadly, graceful move.The BadOur big bad ninja friend moves like a dream in almost every respect except that he seems a little too sticky at times, gluing himself to any and every nearby surface whether you want him too or not.  It's pretty much a necessary game mechanic, but still.  Something to watch out for.OverallI picked this game up as part of a Humble Bundle, and at the time it was just one of those other games I had to take in order to get the two or three I really wanted, but it surprised me by being the absolute best game not only in that whole batch, but one of the best games I've ever played period.  Though I sometimes try to go for 100% completion in my first playthrough of games if it's convenient, I actually went out of my way in order to get it for Mark of the Ninja.  Well, not that far out of my way, because the truth is I simply could not stop playing until it was completely done.  I ended up finishing the entire base game and then came back to Steam to buy up the Special Edition DLC and tore my way through it as well, accomplishing every single challenge and getting every single achievement before I could finally set it aside and move on to another game.I really cannot say enough good things about it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12
												Simply one of the best (if not THE best) stealth platformers I have played.+Awesome graphics and sound.  Easy to understand and use light/dark and sound mechanics.  Great controls.  Several item options for your play style (you can play to kill, distract, or avoid).  The optional styles you unlock add even more options.-Too short.  I say "too short" because I want more.  Really, the way the story plays out, the length is just about right (I completed game, ng+, and 100% achievements in approximately 30 hours).  I really have no complaints.This game was great.  I had a wonderful time playing it.  The side-goals for each mission were fun and some were very challenging.  This is one of those games that gives you the options to play however you want.  It is easy to recommend this game to anyone.
