number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2013
												The graphics are presented in a cartoonish 2D style enviroment with smooth visuals that are very easy on the eyes, despite the constant dark tones. Makes a very nice change from the 8-bit style Indie developers are obsessed about. The animations are well drawn & silky smooth, really bringing life to the game. Watching guards move around with momentum makes them feel more like actual game characters rather than 2D sprites. The death animations are equally as satisfying, if not more so.The game levels are large & leave alot of choice to the player. You can murder every single guard in the game, or use your Ninja tools to slip past without killing a single soul, plus able to turn your enemies against each other, terrifying them into friendly fire incidents. There are multiple pathways throughout each area too. Maybe you want to grapple hook & jump along the rooftops. Or maybe you want to scurry down below in the sewers. It's not often a game gives you such open ended approaches, Think Deus Ex & Dishonored. This is absolutely brilliant!!! Killing enemies itself is quite fun & challenging. You can sneak through an air duct & come across a guard walking above a grate, & you can snatch him through the grate to kill him whilst at the same time hiding his body. Or there can be 2 guards: 1 smoking under a ridge & another patrolling. When the patrolling one is not looking, you can pull a chain round the smoker's neck & yank him up & leave his dead body hanging, & watch the other guard fall over in horror when he sees his former friend hanged from the ceiling, illuminated by a strike of lightening (which is sadistically hilarious to watch).There are some character skills & unlockable upgrades, earned by performing optional challenges in each mission. More killing techniques are always welcome, as well as enhancing your distraction tools and weapons. A few costumes can be unlocked, each with their own perks, such as make no noise when running, but unable to carry a sword. It's a blast to replay a previous level & use new abilities to discover alternate ways to complete the level or reach hidden areas.So while the game is very good, there are some negative points. The controls seriously need alot of work. Buttons conflict with each other: one button is used for both hiding yourself & carrying bodies, & another button used for interaction, jumping & climbing. This leads to situations where there's a body next to a hiding spot, & you want to hide but end up dragging the body & getting shot to death as a result, or wanting to climb around a corner of a ceiling, but end up jumping off into the path of a deadly laser. Why couldn't they have borrowed the idea from Assassins Creed where a button modifies the characters interactions? I'm pretty sure that left bumper on the gamepad is unused by this game.      The controls work most of the time, it's moments like these that lead to frustration. Oh yea & it would be nice if moving the camera lets you choose specific targets instead of having to use the movement keys to do so, it doesn't make sense otherwise. This leads to the character moving in order to target enemies, possibly moving too much & either losing sight of the target or getting spotted as a result.     They did try to vary the enviroment a fair bit, unfortunately later levels start to suffer, particularly the platforming one, a level with sandstorms with explosive mines, & the ones taking place in caves which don't offer much freedom of movement.     While not a major issue, it would be nice to see a bit more varied animations. There seems to be only 2 death animations for each kill type & some of them seem to play rarely. The animations are so good in this game that I'd like to see more! To wrap things up, this game is an absolute must have!! It's stealth mechanics are both appealing to hardcore & casual players, the visuals are very pleasing, there's tons of replayability, as well as encouraging you to use different playstyles. Being a Ninja has never been so much fun!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												"The best stealth game ever made?"Not sure about that. I would still give this title to Thief 2. That said, Klei seems to have a talent of creating brilliant games no matter what genre they reach for and MoN is no different.Great artstyle mixing western-style animation and Japanese themes. This 2d stealth game allowing for variety of approaches. You want to sneak? You can. You want to murder everyone in the room? You can. You want to murder one guard and hung him high to terrify other guards, who the fall to their deaths, or shoot other guards. You can. While levels aren't complex as in earlier mentioned original Thief games or Hitman: Blood Money, they are designed well enough to allow for different paths and encourage exploration. Add to that really solid game mechanics which allow you to make your own path if you feel like it, by distracting enemies or taking out guards in ways not specifficaly designed by creators. The UI makes sure that whatever you do you know hom much noise you make and who and how can hear you.  Thanks to this you always know how much noise you make and can plan your moves accordingly.Anything bad? The writing could be better. While the story is pretty solid and the little "Haiku scrolls" you find in every level are brilliant, I am not a big fan of the dialogue in the game. It is just too dry and character-less. Still, a must buy for anyone even remotely interested in stealth games.

												one of the best stealth games i've played, and 'till now, the best title from klei (haven't played invisible inc. that much tho). the graphics are stylish, the plot is simple but it's thrilling and it makes you want to continue playing until it is finished, the gameplay allows for multiple approaches, you can just kill the ♥♥♥♥ out of everyone or get past silently, ant the difficulty... well, that is a hard point to discuss. The difficulty itself is kinda hard, but the checkpoint system is too forgiving, it saves before and aftes any major encounter, but you are going to fail. multiple times. you'll hit that restart checkpoint button so many times (if you wanna get it right, tho. as i said before you can ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥up, keep running straight and boom, you finish the level, but that's not the way it's meant to be played, so if you wanna embrace the experience of the ninja, you gotta play it right, and it's hard) you'll kiss the developers♥♥♥♥♥for those recurring checkpoints. that being said, it's not a hard game because of the checkpoints, but if you try and play without them, you're pretty much ♥♥♥♥ed.I recommend it strongly, get it right now.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Mark of the Ninja is one of the best stealth games, one of the best platformers, and one of the best ninja games in recent years.  With a gameplay style that rewards tactical precision while still keeping a brisk pace, the game manages to work your brain and reflexes in a way that feels exciting and familiar as a player.  The story is clichéd but sincere, the levels are more videogame than reality, and sometimes you'll encounter a loophole or exploit to take away your immersion in favor of ratcheting up your score, but you'll enjoy every minute of it.  Every challenge is met with enjoyment.  No part of the game ever feels like it drags or has that "boring act" structure.The gameplay is finely tuned, with inspiration from every major stealth title out there put to good use.  Nothing is wasted; everything is fun.  There's little higher praise than that.And it has the best type of New Game + mode, where the fundamental mechanics are altered significantly for a heightened challenge.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												Pretty Good Game Review Considering (PGGRC) 6.1 Hours to Complete TL;DR - YES I DO RECOMMEND THIS AMAZING AND SURPIRSE OF A GAME. Wow never has a 2D game been so strategic. When the stealth mechanics work so fluent, slick and has more stealth mechanics of other games but way less of the budget you know you have a great dev that understands what games are about.In depth:Performance - Its 2D and runs on almost anything. Graphics - Even though it run on almost everything doesn’t think this game is a pig. This game is a beauty. Not only from the beautiful Japanese’s inspired art style but from the landscapes and even character design. Gameplay - It’s quite a short game (depending on playstyles, I’ll get too that in a bit :) and quite easy (if you don’t care about score or challenges). If you don’t care about challenges then you won’t be able to upgrade your gear which you will need. Every gadget and clothing has a purpose and is different from one another and actually offers a different playstyle. Whether you pick the stealth armour, allowing moving silently and holding more non-lethal gadgets or an amour that makes you feel like a juggernaugh allowing you to rip people apart or even armour allowing you to teleport to completely leave the enemies untouched. Needed more enemy design also to vary up engagements. Ending needed to be better if the story was compelling or if each ending showed the aftermath of each choice, it would actually be worth it but the payoff lacked as pacing and depth was non-existent. Just note that the "DLC" MISSION NOT STORY IS AWFUL. Lasts TEN MINIUTES FOR ♥♥♥♥ SAKE and lacks any different content aside from few gear and costume you can use in the main game. Very disappointing.Replayability - For all unlocks, two endings (not worth replaying it for to be honest as story is weak sauce) and different playstyles as well as how fun it is, yes it’s worth it. Conclusion - This game offers a lot for a low price. Has more depth in stealth mechanics than assassin’s creed for crying out loud. Fun, fluent and varied. The game looks and feels beautiful and if the story had build up and character it would be a perfect game.If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow my curator group: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/FALLENV3GAS#curation

												Another good pitch for my favourate game. Mark of the Ninja shows how to do stealth games properly. Your visable or your not, they can hear you or they can't. All expressed by the visual and artistic choices of the development team. Rings of sound raidiate from you or objects in the real world, ring crosses an enemy before it dissipates, too bad. Enemies can enter carying states, if one finds a corpse you so delicatly dangled from that pipe?  Now he is ♥♥♥♥ing terrified. Time-outs for being spotted barely last 10s, kill the person who spotted you before he raises the alarm. Panic over. Kill him after? Well others are still coming, sprint and they will hear you, hide who knows if they will find you and stay to meet a prompt death. Waiting is fun in this game, the 2D visuals make it "clear" every alternative path (not counting secret areas) and while your hiding away from the flashlights and drama, you have a moment to re-evaluate the route and see the new enemy positions. At the end you face a dilema. You do things by mistake, thing's you cannot fix. Will you continue on, as you did from moment one after your moment of truth or will you make a sacrifice.

content:

												This is indeed the first game that I have successfully played through on steam and I must say I am very very impressed with pretty much everything it had to offer. Though I must probaby add that I have only just completed the normal game mode. And, boy, was that an awesome experience.It offers amazing visual and sound effects actually helping you on your way through, which also create the majestic piece of art that this game is. The levels get gradually harder (although not too hard) and you gain more skills/items as you go. The different puzzles you have to solve make for an exciting brain tease with a rewarding "YES"-effect after you've managed to trick those pesky guards. The story (if you decide to read through and follow mentally) is rather thrilling and you really feel involved into the actual outcome.I have played it with a controller and it did feel surprisingly easy to manouver and execute any sneaky action I attempted. I have also loved the tooltips about all the aspects of the creation of the game. It really gives the player a relatively good insight in what it takes to create certain aspects of the game.Overall an impressive game that actually brings what it takes to be an assassin. If you are looking for THE assassin game out there right now, I'd point you in this direction.Personal rating 10/10. I really can't find any bad aspect about the game right now, except for it lacking a second part, which I am suspecting will come out at some point (haven't checked yet)

												I went into Mark of the Ninja only knowing one thing, it's a game about Ninja's. When I got into the game I was met with great graphics, great cinematic cutscenes, a good story, difficult puzzles (later in the game) and best of all challenging gameplay. My favorite part is that you can play the game 3 ways, violently (kill everyone), stealthily (unseen yet the most challenging) or a mix of the two. So, would I recommend this game, yes! While the new game plus may seem unfair at first, it challenges you as a gamer, not only your reflexes but your skill. The difficulty curve is quite fair as well, so give this game a shot. Oh and by the way, this game reflects what real ninjas should be like: not killing everyone in their path, and staying hidden.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2016
												Mark of the Ninja is the best stealth game since Thief 1/2. If you want a stealth game, you won't find a better one. Unlike the Thief games, MotN plays in 2D; however the transition from 3D to 2D doesn't mean it's less complex than the Thief games. You'll still have to be careful not to be seen, not to make too much noise and there are many side objectives in every level to keep things interesting.All gameplay systems come together perfectly in the best stealth game in recent times. It's so good that I 100%ed it - MoTn is the first Steam game where I've completed every achievement and I've done everything there is to be done (it took me ~20 hours including the DLC level, so there's good value for your money). Besides GOAT tier gameplay, MotN also offers a simple but powerful story that complements the gameplay perfectly. Graphics are nice, consisting of cartoon like sprites which are superbly animated. Sounds are deeply connected to the game's stealth system and are well implemented. And the level design is amazing. Seriously. Every level is built in such way to make you feel like the most badass ninja to ever exist (which in the context of the game, you are). Kudos to the level designer. There are also unlockables that you earn after each level/side objective. And after you complete the main campaign there's also a New Game+ mode, for that 'no kill run' you'll want to do.When I was a kid, I used to play a lot on my ZX Spectrum and one of my favourite games was Saboteur, a game that made me feel like a ninja. ~30 years later, MotN reminded me of Saboteur, not from a gameplay pov but because it gave me the same "omg amazing best game ever" feel. All in all, I have no bad things to say about this game. If you want to feel like a ninja, try MotN. If you want to play the best stealth game since the original Thief games, play MotN. It's truly a must play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												RECOMMENDATION-(Yes/No & Why):-Yes,The game story is awesome and you should get this game with the dlc because the dlc completes the story and its cheap.INTRODUCTION:-Mark of the Ninja was released in mid 2012 originally for the Xbox Live Arcade and eventually released on Steam. It is a 2D side scrolling Stealth game which delivers gameplay which heavily emphasizes stealth combat (either Lethal or Non-Lethal). It has then received several critical acclaim from both players and critics alike.-The player takes on the role of "The Marked One", an unnamed Ninja from the Hisomu Clan during the modern (relatively futuristic) world. After a massive attack by a heavily armed and technologically superior mercenary group on your home Dojo, the Marked One awakens to find himself tagged by mysterious tattoos which grant him unrivaled skills and ability. Use this new found powers to drive away the invaders and uncover their plans.PROS:+ Nice quality graphics specially for a 2D Game+ Very Well Made Stealth mechanic +The Soundtracks are very asian style and that´s pretty cool.+ Good character progression that accomodate different playstylesm like you can use playstyle like killing with sword,bare hand knockout or just sneak pass them.+Nice Puzzles plus there is Challenge Rooms hidden in each levels.+ High replay value+ Mission objectives can be approached and completed in multiple ways plus the map level is very big.CONS:- The Controls are a little messy but when you get to the third level you get used to it .- Some puzzles are repetitive and frustrating-No Level Editor-No non-lethal option for Bosses-No Workshop-No MultiplayerConclusion:-The Game is awesome and you should pick it with the dlc ,this game delievers one of the best ninja stealth experiences in 2D Version plus the soundtracks ,animations and graphics are pretty cool.If you like stealth games like this one you should really pick it at sale or even in full price 100% worth it buying .Note: If you wish to correct anything in this review add me but first read my profile.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												This is an outstanding little game. The art style is terrific. The game looks unique and visually appealing. Though more sophisticated, the look has elements reminiscent of Samurai Jack (epic cartoon by the way). The biggest draw for me was that you are a ninja, you get to sneak around wielding the mighty sword of Tetsuji a while doing stealth kills that are brutal and awesome (childhood fantasy fulfilled).The level design is excellent, the puzzles are clever and challenging but not so punishing that you’ll get frustrated. A big plus is that when you do fail, the game reloads almost immediately so you can try again, a little wiser with each death. So many games drag out your death, or you have to wait an eternity for them to reload, it just makes you ram your head into your monitor.Finally, the game does an excellent job of telling a good story. The levels are immersive and have great atmosphere, the characters are developed well enough for you to become attached to them and they balance the narrative so you can appreciate both sides.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Great game ! Will grab from beginning to end.Though it suffers from a few minor imperfections (QTE-based combat, some badly placed checkpoints, etc.), on the whole it's glorious. The stealth mechanic are very well done, and it's a pleasure to use the differents tools to get rid of the guards.Do know that the game is fairly easy, so you may want to give yourself some challenges to make it more fun. Basically except for pacifist run, everything in the game should be easy for people used to stealth mechanics. New game plus will offer a higher difficulty, but since I dislike playing the same game twice, i can't talk about it.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												I went into Mark of the Ninja only knowing one thing, it's a game about Ninja's. When I got into the game I was met with great graphics, great cinematic cutscenes, a good story, difficult puzzles (later in the game) and best of all challenging gameplay. My favorite part is that you can play the game 3 ways, violently (kill everyone), stealthily (unseen yet the most challenging) or a mix of the two. So, would I recommend this game, yes! While the new game plus may seem unfair at first, it challenges you as a gamer, not only your reflexes but your skill. The difficulty curve is quite fair as well, so give this game a shot. Oh and by the way, this game reflects what real ninjas should be like: not killing everyone in their path, and staying hidden.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												Mark of the Ninja is hands down one of the best stealth games out on the market. Easily one of the best games in my library, and that I would proudly recommend to anybody that loves the stealth genre. So to save some time I will just make a list.Pros: The Skill unlocks are well balanced throughout the game Wonderful combat Gives the feeling that you can be dicovered and killed in mear seconds. Removing that feeling of tanky-ness most games give. Art style is defenitly great with the backdrops and the character models really adding a wonderful kinda grim feel to the game Suits have different functions each giving them their own way of play that level which really adds some replayability. The abilities are really amazing with some solid animations. No experience of bugs or problems so farCons: Story can be a bit dull at times  Not super amazed by the point system and feel it is kinda useless unless you are a completionist (more of an opinion then a con)  I feel their could be more variety when it comes to guard arangment and possibilities to get through the levelOverall I would give it a 9/10 in my books.This is one of the rare games in my library that I have played to the end and then played again.It's art style and overall theme just serves a really nice atmosphere even when the plot can be lacking at times.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												This is indeed the first game that I have successfully played through on steam and I must say I am very very impressed with pretty much everything it had to offer. Though I must probaby add that I have only just completed the normal game mode. And, boy, was that an awesome experience.It offers amazing visual and sound effects actually helping you on your way through, which also create the majestic piece of art that this game is. The levels get gradually harder (although not too hard) and you gain more skills/items as you go. The different puzzles you have to solve make for an exciting brain tease with a rewarding "YES"-effect after you've managed to trick those pesky guards. The story (if you decide to read through and follow mentally) is rather thrilling and you really feel involved into the actual outcome.I have played it with a controller and it did feel surprisingly easy to manouver and execute any sneaky action I attempted. I have also loved the tooltips about all the aspects of the creation of the game. It really gives the player a relatively good insight in what it takes to create certain aspects of the game.Overall an impressive game that actually brings what it takes to be an assassin. If you are looking for THE assassin game out there right now, I'd point you in this direction.Personal rating 10/10. I really can't find any bad aspect about the game right now, except for it lacking a second part, which I am suspecting will come out at some point (haven't checked yet)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2012
												If you like stealth games and you've already beaten the Deus Ex series, Thief series, Death to Spies series and the first three Splinter Cell games, but still want more, I'd strongly recommend Mark of the Ninja.MotN is definitely an action-stealth game, so combat plays a heavier role (in the form of stealth kills) than in the aforementioned stealth titles.  That said, you can generally avoid combat and sometimes that's a smarter tactic anyway.  If you're generally anti-console, don't let the fact this game was first released for XBox Live put you off.  It works great with a mouse-and-keyboard setup (and most controllers work too).The one downside to MotN is its save game system, which shows its console roots: it only saves between levels and uses checkpoints during them, so you can't save when and where you want.  The good news, however, is that checkpoints are all over the place and at most you'll find yourself set back maybe a few minutes if you die.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2013
												This game reminds me of the old Splinter Cell.Gameplay-10/10  Stealth mechanics are solid and as you complete objectives you learn new methods to assassinate your opponents. Interface-10/10  Minimalistic interface when you are hiding. The game displays everything you need when you are detected or performing an action. I can't think of a way to improve it; it's that well done. Controller works fine with this game.Visuals-8/10  I like the style.Plot-4/10  Resounding meh. I honestly can't recall the plot even though I just played the game. You are a ninja! End of story.Haiku Poems-8/10  You need to solve a puzzle to collect them. I enjoyed solving the puzzles and listening to the narrated poems helped immerse me into the setting.Overall Experience-8/10 A must play if you like the old Splinter Cell.If you want to take your enemies head on, you might want to play Samurai Showdown or CoD; because ninjas primarily focus on stealth and traps to take out their enemies.Update 11/28/2016: Still a great game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												This game is great and am really enjoying it.  It is overall very well made:  comic book-esque animation beautifully done including animated cut scenes; voice acting is very quality; controls with a Playstation (and I assume Xbox) are very good and fit perfectly with the gameplay, which also very excellent and fun (I have not tried playing with a keyboard and/or mouse).  I am also enjoying the plot so far.The best way I can inadequetely describe the game is a wonderful side scrolling combination of Tenchu and stealth/predator aspects of the recent Batman Arkham games that is completely unique in its own way and doesn't feel derivitive of either.My only minor quibble is that I wish there were more variation in the stealth kills, both requiring more variety in skill/button combinations to execute as well as more variety in execution moves/deaths, though I am not very far in the game and these may have already been implemented, just haven't gotten there yet.I got this on sale, but I would have been fine if I had paid the full price (which is currently $14.99), and I highly recommend this game to anyone whom finds the above description appealing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												This is one of those games where they have nailed the rules. The rules are simple, and the gameplay is simple. After you understand what you are doing you can just go ahead and finish it, but that is where it really begins. The original game feels like a training mode for everything that you do after that. Finding every scroll, fulfilling all of the coniditions, and hitting the required scores to three star everything pushes you to play differently throughout.Then the game begins again with 'New Game Plus'. New game plus changes the rules, but they are still clear, and pushes you to master new tactics, and assess your environment on the fly. Then once you have completed that, you can go through and master different modes of play. I am currently trying to 'ghost' every level on 'New Game Plus'. That isn't an achievement, but I want to do it.Mark of the Ninja will reward you with hours of entertainment for finding your own ways to play the game.

Posted: December 24, 2012
												Moving stealth into 2d may seem like oversimplification, but here it clarifies, turning every step into a puzzle of timing and tools. Mark of the Ninja is probably one of the best stealth games in a while because it removes the guesswork and trial and error of many stealth games. It's also very solid in that no tool or toy goes wasted, and I can't remember any device going unused. It's also a fair deal longer than I expected, and I'm looking forward to playing on a higher difficulty, something I rarely worry about these days with my game collection being what it is. Both very true to (ridiculous) ninja mythology and probably the most fun you might have as a ninja on the PC.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2013
												What makes this game a masterpiece is the "terrorize" feature. When an NPC experiences something traumatic (eg you stealthily murder someone and then hang their corpse from a lamp-post for an unsuspecting guard to discover), they become "terrorized". They hyperventilate, abandon their normal patrol, and panickingly shoot anything that moves or even makes a sound (including their allies). I fondly remember scaring the crap out of some dude who stumbled over the ledge next to which he happened to be standing on and fell to his death. This feeling of empowerment, of being an unseen and silent terror that makes others truly afraid of the dark, juxtaposed with the disempowerment of being outnumbered and outgunned, is what makes this game a work of genius.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
Chase 'em down, string 'em upDisclaimer: This review contains big words and actual english. If this seems frightening or overbearing, feel free to ignore this review, and refer to the average 3-line steam review of your choice. But if you do, you're pretty much a troglodyte.Mark of the Ninja is a 2d stealth game by Klei, the same guys who made Shank and Shank 2. The same buttery fluid animations and art direction are present in Mark of the Ninja. Quite frankly, the game looks amazing in motion. Once you get the hang of the controls and the environments, you put whatever the current-gen protagonists of Assassin's Creed are called to shame. That's inadequate, you make the free-running elements in AC look like a geriatric with a crutches by comparison.The story, so far (I've yet to beat it), is rather straight-forward stuff. You've gotten inked by your clan's tattooist Dosan, with ink which heightens your senses and gives you a convenient array of abilities that are mainstays in video games. But the downside is that the ink burns you out, and will ultimately drive you mad. So you've taken this Mark, in order to undertake a mission to safeguard your clan's existence. And once you've completed your task, you're going to kill yourself. Before that though, truckloads upon truckloads of henchmen are going to get theirs. Alternatively, they will not even know you were there.Klei made the Shank games. Shank games are 80-ish action homages as sidescrolling beat-em-up. MotN is the AC/Batman/Splinter Cell/Tenchu/Sneak-em-up treatment of a sidescroller. You have essentially complete freedom in how you choose to undertake your missions. And by how, I mean the level of lethality and bloodshed that will befall those who made the poor career choices that culminated in ending up on the wrong side of your blade. Or those ninja traps you will unlock or buy eventually. Or, you will just quietly slip by them. Hiding in doorways, behind potted plants, crawling past them on the ceiling, grappling from lamp-post to lamp-post above their heads, sneaking in the vents below or above them. The sneaking is really good. Like REALLY good, REALLY good.Your equipment at first consists of firecrackers for distraction, a sword for stealth killing (kills are executed like a QTE, but not nearly as annoying. You press a direction and X to cut someone up), and that's all you got at first. Later on you get a grappling hook, spike traps which work like land mines, smoke bombs and more fun stuff to play around with.There are challenge rooms you might encounter (they look like gongs), which mix up the regular levels by being more of platforming challenges/puzzles. They use the normal game elements to complete, which manages to both freshen up how you think about the environments and traps/hazards in the game, as well as giving you a fresh lease on how to approach situations in subsequent levels.I know a lot of game reviews fall prey to the pitfalls of hyperbole and similes, and I've already planted my foot firmly in that territory. And I kinda detest that. But honestly, it's impossible to do it when talking about MotN. Hell, it's just straight-up amazing. The stealth&stalk bits are great. The array of gadgets are groovy, as is the techniques you unlock with honor points as you complete levels. Some of them are different types of stealth kills, while another lessen the sound you make while sprinting, or allow you to string up dead guard from lamp posts in order to frighten other guards senseless. You can actually terrify guards to the point of them losing it completely, where they just start shooting wildly at everything they see or imagine they see. The only downside so far, is that sometimes it's a bit wonky whether you get the bonus for hiding bodies or not, and you might have to drop them a couple of times before it registers. Or possibly that's just left in there as a reference to Metal Gear Solid games. I'm not putting it past these devs, this is obviously a labour of love.This is definitely a high-score type of operation, and I'm gonna come back to these levels. You're scored on stealth kills.You're scored on sneaking past guards closely while remaining undetected, and on distracting them.You're scored on equipment kills, on terrifying guards (and the possible resulting friendly fire), and hiding bodies.In each level, you can find 3 scrolls which tell the story of your clan and how it came to be, and what led up to you taking on the Mark in the first place. These also give you a point of honor each, which is used to purchase upgrades inbetween missions or at banner stops within levels.There are also 3 seals per level. Seals are the same thing as optional objectives or challenges.These seals fall into Path of Hunter, Combat, Nightmares or Shadow. (Names subject to making-up by me, just now, seeing as it's late and I can't be arsed to start the game to be correct.) Completing enough of these nets you new outfits with special pros and cons. For instance, the sneaky suit silences the sound of running feet, and allows you to carry 2 distraction items in your loadout. But the tradeoff is your sword. For anyone who enjoys 2d games with tight controls, this is a must.For anyone who enjoys cartoon violence, this is a must.If you've ever played a game that had a great single-player campaign, but was hamstrung by a forced multiplayer that was just put in there in order to sell the game to people who think singleplayer games are a waste of time, you need to get this in order to support the practice of making "great games that don't need no multiplayer".For anyone who played and enjoyed any of the stealth elements in any of the recent Arkham games, this is a must.For anyone who has ever daydreamed of being a ninja, this is a must....I just want slap a "MUST BUY" sticker on this.The rest of all the games I bought this holiday sale and have yet to play might turn out to be complete♥♥♥♥♥♥ but Mark of the Ninja more than makes up for that possibility.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2013
												Nice stealh-action platformer with plenty of interesting gameplay quirks.  Get it right and you're sneaking through a complex, evading, slipping past and jumping out on guards.  Taking them out, hiding the bodies, stringing them up to "terrorise" the rest of the enemy, or just slipping past  within inches of them disabling the lights and dropping smoke or even just slipping inside a convenient box or behind a nearby vase.Going all-out violence isn't rewarded but even fleeing when spotted can be a valid tactic if you can get out of sight well enough.  A nice vision and sound system to evade detection or provide distraction, and it all works quite well.Reminds me quite a bit of Saboteur on the ZX Spectrum.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												My first impression of this game was a quick little stealth title to hold me over for an hour or two. Little did I know that I would have eventually put in nearly 30 hours of quality gaming into this artistic masterpiece.Right off the bat I could tell how polished and clean the graphics were. What really made the game sing were the simple lighting effects and the amazing depth of field they added. Depth of field in a 2D game! Who would've thought. Basically, whatever isn't in your character's line of sight is blurry. Simple yet added a nice touch to the game. The running, killing, climbing, etc animations were all fluid and sexy. Nice simple cinematics added to the feel of the game.So it looks great, and sounds just as good. I love the ambiance in the game. The drums are my favorite, really sets the pace of the game. Audio is nice and smooth, nothing sounded off while playing.The gameplay itself was something unexpected. It started off simple, and got more complex as it continued. I had no problems finishing the levels while either killing everyone or not killing anyone. Most levels had several paths and ways to handle every situation. Even more so, with the array of tools you're provided to handle missions. I honestly never came to a part of the game that frustrated me, or made me want to rage quit. With each obstacle presented, I had fun figuring out the best way to handle each situation. Mark of the Ninja is going on my top list of favorite games. It's well worth the $15 asking price, regardless of any kind of steam sale. Crossing my fingers for a sequel.

												This is a fun stealth and Metroidvania game. I liked the story. Lots of ways to earn points not only by killing but going unnoticed by enemies and hiding corpses. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Coming into this game, I didn't have very high expectations - after all, stealth/action isn't really my genre. As I played it, however, I found that many elements of gameplay are quite satisfying. I feel that the game had good player direction, as I never felt that I was being led along, but I also never felt confused as to where I needed to go. The question I would often ask myself was not, "What am I supposed to do?" but rather, "How am I going to do it?". It's an incredibly fun experience being able to assess a situation, and recognize multiple ways of approaching the situation.The art and animation in the cutscenes is done exceptionally well, and for some reason I find myself thinking back on Samurai Jack whenever I see it. In-level art is also done in a way that keeps everything dark and fitting for the mood, but still clearly recognizable to the player through the use of silhouettes.All in all, I would say that this game is a good choice for those who like stealth action, and even for those who want to try something new and fun.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												10/10 - Please make a sequel (or three) for this game. Please. Really, please..I was pleasantly surprised by this game to say the least. If you're a fan of stealth you're very likely to enjoy it. The graphic style is wonderful and doesn't distract from the gameplay. The animations are very enjoyable and the difficulty is tuned perfectly. The sounds, music and voiceovers are perfect. The ambiance pulls you in and doesn't let go.If there was a sequel made to this I'd be a pre-order customer instantly. A co-op version of this would be great as well. I can easily see two characters sneaking around various levels, working together to disarm traps, quietly getting around guards either by stealth or cooperative distratctions, etc. Even a player vs player mode could easily be done. Two ninjas on a map trying to take each other out either by fighting or setting traps or distracting guards in the direction of the enemy.. Tell you what, just hire me and I'll share all my ideas. :) On a serious note however, get this game. Get it and free up your schedule. It's extremely good and one of the few games in my library I've not only completed but will very likely return to several times. And if you have the opportunity, grab the special edition with the development notes scattered throughout the game. They're very interesting (like a DVD commentary track) and unobtrusive. I've never seen such a thing done in a game, but after seeing it in this game I'd actually love this option in more games (wth an option to turn on/off completely).Great job team, great game. Now get to making the sequels!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2012
												If you like stealth games and you've already beaten the Deus Ex series, Thief series, Death to Spies series and the first three Splinter Cell games, but still want more, I'd strongly recommend Mark of the Ninja.MotN is definitely an action-stealth game, so combat plays a heavier role (in the form of stealth kills) than in the aforementioned stealth titles.  That said, you can generally avoid combat and sometimes that's a smarter tactic anyway.  If you're generally anti-console, don't let the fact this game was first released for XBox Live put you off.  It works great with a mouse-and-keyboard setup (and most controllers work too).The one downside to MotN is its save game system, which shows its console roots: it only saves between levels and uses checkpoints during them, so you can't save when and where you want.  The good news, however, is that checkpoints are all over the place and at most you'll find yourself set back maybe a few minutes if you die.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2013
												This game reminds me of the old Splinter Cell.Gameplay-10/10  Stealth mechanics are solid and as you complete objectives you learn new methods to assassinate your opponents. Interface-10/10  Minimalistic interface when you are hiding. The game displays everything you need when you are detected or performing an action. I can't think of a way to improve it; it's that well done. Controller works fine with this game.Visuals-8/10  I like the style.Plot-4/10  Resounding meh. I honestly can't recall the plot even though I just played the game. You are a ninja! End of story.Haiku Poems-8/10  You need to solve a puzzle to collect them. I enjoyed solving the puzzles and listening to the narrated poems helped immerse me into the setting.Overall Experience-8/10 A must play if you like the old Splinter Cell.If you want to take your enemies head on, you might want to play Samurai Showdown or CoD; because ninjas primarily focus on stealth and traps to take out their enemies.Update 11/28/2016: Still a great game!

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												This is one of the most innovative games I have ever played. Like the reviews say, it is a testament to stealth based games. I felt more like an assassin here than in Assassin's Creed II. I am not bashing Assassin's Creed at all, I love it, but it doesn't pull off stealth based platforming like Mark of the Ninja. This game has amazing replayability, with different items and costumes to fit different playstyles. For instance, in every level you can bypass without killing anyone, using the suit of darkness. The items in this game allow the entire game to be played in different and more challenging ways. I highly suggest it if you are into good humored, amazing platforming and really feeling like a ninja.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
Chase 'em down, string 'em upDisclaimer: This review contains big words and actual english. If this seems frightening or overbearing, feel free to ignore this review, and refer to the average 3-line steam review of your choice. But if you do, you're pretty much a troglodyte.Mark of the Ninja is a 2d stealth game by Klei, the same guys who made Shank and Shank 2. The same buttery fluid animations and art direction are present in Mark of the Ninja. Quite frankly, the game looks amazing in motion. Once you get the hang of the controls and the environments, you put whatever the current-gen protagonists of Assassin's Creed are called to shame. That's inadequate, you make the free-running elements in AC look like a geriatric with a crutches by comparison.The story, so far (I've yet to beat it), is rather straight-forward stuff. You've gotten inked by your clan's tattooist Dosan, with ink which heightens your senses and gives you a convenient array of abilities that are mainstays in video games. But the downside is that the ink burns you out, and will ultimately drive you mad. So you've taken this Mark, in order to undertake a mission to safeguard your clan's existence. And once you've completed your task, you're going to kill yourself. Before that though, truckloads upon truckloads of henchmen are going to get theirs. Alternatively, they will not even know you were there.Klei made the Shank games. Shank games are 80-ish action homages as sidescrolling beat-em-up. MotN is the AC/Batman/Splinter Cell/Tenchu/Sneak-em-up treatment of a sidescroller. You have essentially complete freedom in how you choose to undertake your missions. And by how, I mean the level of lethality and bloodshed that will befall those who made the poor career choices that culminated in ending up on the wrong side of your blade. Or those ninja traps you will unlock or buy eventually. Or, you will just quietly slip by them. Hiding in doorways, behind potted plants, crawling past them on the ceiling, grappling from lamp-post to lamp-post above their heads, sneaking in the vents below or above them. The sneaking is really good. Like REALLY good, REALLY good.Your equipment at first consists of firecrackers for distraction, a sword for stealth killing (kills are executed like a QTE, but not nearly as annoying. You press a direction and X to cut someone up), and that's all you got at first. Later on you get a grappling hook, spike traps which work like land mines, smoke bombs and more fun stuff to play around with.There are challenge rooms you might encounter (they look like gongs), which mix up the regular levels by being more of platforming challenges/puzzles. They use the normal game elements to complete, which manages to both freshen up how you think about the environments and traps/hazards in the game, as well as giving you a fresh lease on how to approach situations in subsequent levels.I know a lot of game reviews fall prey to the pitfalls of hyperbole and similes, and I've already planted my foot firmly in that territory. And I kinda detest that. But honestly, it's impossible to do it when talking about MotN. Hell, it's just straight-up amazing. The stealth&stalk bits are great. The array of gadgets are groovy, as is the techniques you unlock with honor points as you complete levels. Some of them are different types of stealth kills, while another lessen the sound you make while sprinting, or allow you to string up dead guard from lamp posts in order to frighten other guards senseless. You can actually terrify guards to the point of them losing it completely, where they just start shooting wildly at everything they see or imagine they see. The only downside so far, is that sometimes it's a bit wonky whether you get the bonus for hiding bodies or not, and you might have to drop them a couple of times before it registers. Or possibly that's just left in there as a reference to Metal Gear Solid games. I'm not putting it past these devs, this is obviously a labour of love.This is definitely a high-score type of operation, and I'm gonna come back to these levels. You're scored on stealth kills.You're scored on sneaking past guards closely while remaining undetected, and on distracting them.You're scored on equipment kills, on terrifying guards (and the possible resulting friendly fire), and hiding bodies.In each level, you can find 3 scrolls which tell the story of your clan and how it came to be, and what led up to you taking on the Mark in the first place. These also give you a point of honor each, which is used to purchase upgrades inbetween missions or at banner stops within levels.There are also 3 seals per level. Seals are the same thing as optional objectives or challenges.These seals fall into Path of Hunter, Combat, Nightmares or Shadow. (Names subject to making-up by me, just now, seeing as it's late and I can't be arsed to start the game to be correct.) Completing enough of these nets you new outfits with special pros and cons. For instance, the sneaky suit silences the sound of running feet, and allows you to carry 2 distraction items in your loadout. But the tradeoff is your sword. For anyone who enjoys 2d games with tight controls, this is a must.For anyone who enjoys cartoon violence, this is a must.If you've ever played a game that had a great single-player campaign, but was hamstrung by a forced multiplayer that was just put in there in order to sell the game to people who think singleplayer games are a waste of time, you need to get this in order to support the practice of making "great games that don't need no multiplayer".For anyone who played and enjoyed any of the stealth elements in any of the recent Arkham games, this is a must.For anyone who has ever daydreamed of being a ninja, this is a must....I just want slap a "MUST BUY" sticker on this.The rest of all the games I bought this holiday sale and have yet to play might turn out to be complete♥♥♥♥♥♥ but Mark of the Ninja more than makes up for that possibility.

												I've got it figured out for Keyboard & Mouse. I've completed the first level and am updating my review to say, yeah, this is fun. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												This is one of those games where they have nailed the rules. The rules are simple, and the gameplay is simple. After you understand what you are doing you can just go ahead and finish it, but that is where it really begins. The original game feels like a training mode for everything that you do after that. Finding every scroll, fulfilling all of the coniditions, and hitting the required scores to three star everything pushes you to play differently throughout.Then the game begins again with 'New Game Plus'. New game plus changes the rules, but they are still clear, and pushes you to master new tactics, and assess your environment on the fly. Then once you have completed that, you can go through and master different modes of play. I am currently trying to 'ghost' every level on 'New Game Plus'. That isn't an achievement, but I want to do it.Mark of the Ninja will reward you with hours of entertainment for finding your own ways to play the game.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2013
												Nice stealh-action platformer with plenty of interesting gameplay quirks.  Get it right and you're sneaking through a complex, evading, slipping past and jumping out on guards.  Taking them out, hiding the bodies, stringing them up to "terrorise" the rest of the enemy, or just slipping past  within inches of them disabling the lights and dropping smoke or even just slipping inside a convenient box or behind a nearby vase.Going all-out violence isn't rewarded but even fleeing when spotted can be a valid tactic if you can get out of sight well enough.  A nice vision and sound system to evade detection or provide distraction, and it all works quite well.Reminds me quite a bit of Saboteur on the ZX Spectrum.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2013
												Mark of the Ninja makes stealth cool again. No frustration, just the raw satisfaction of being a silent and deadly badass. Visual cues show if you're about to be detected, so there's enough time to get away. If you do make a mistake, there are frequent checkpoints and the reload is instant. Getting through a level without being spotted is very much possible, and more importantly: a lot of fun.I'd heard nothing but good things about MotN, but nothing prepared me for its sheer brilliance. Clearly a labour of love.

												The greatest stealth game for me is Thief: The Dark Project, for being a sneaky dark wonderland full of rich, thoughtful medieval-era fantasy weirdness. Mark of the Ninja is definitely within the same stealth-based awesomeness circle. The mechanics are sound and murdering dudes is ♥♥♥♥ing satisfying, and the tools unlocked during the game add onto the fun that is murdering dudes. However, the storytelling is garbage and the art is still Disney mixed with Penny Arcade, but there's always the ancillary romance created from the relationship of your sword and some poor mercenary's back.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2012
												Put simply, Mark of the Ninja is one of the best interpretations of the stealth genre we've seen in years.  If you found yourself put off by the developer's earlier efforts, please do not let that keep you from giving this amazing game a go. The stealth mechanics are brilliantly thought out and cater to a variety of playstyles, the stages are thoughtfully designed with many paths toward objectives, and there are enough optional challenges to keep you busy for quite a while. Mark of the Ninja is just straight-up one of the best games of 2012. It's satisfying and fun to play, looks absolutely fatnastic, and has a story that requires studying the subtle nuances to fully enjoy. I'm hard-pressed to think of what more one could ask for, especially given this game's price point.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Mark of the Ninja is perhaps the greatest stealth game of all time, and certainly the greatest 2D stealth game (in my opinion). The whole experience looks and plays great. There is never a moment where I do not feel completely in control of the character, and when a mistake is made, I know exactly how I fouled up and can do better next time. The gameplay fits with the plot of the game and the whole is presented beautifully, like a blood-soaked, action-packed cartoon. One of my favourite games of all time, and one that I've so far played from start to finish three times and will install and play again on a regular basis. Heartily recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2013
												Mark of the Ninja... it's a game... well... about a Ninja, that has a mark. Go figure.It's a 2D side-scroller-ish game featuring a nameless Ninja that was branded with a toxic tattoo that enhances his ninja powers, but at the same time also drives him insane. He must then commit suicide before madness fully engulfs him.... and I'm not going to tell the rest of the story because it would be a huge spoiler.Talking about the actual game, it does have an interesting stealth mechanism and various tools that can be used for deception... or to kill. Well designed levels, although a bit linear (2D sidescroller, there's not much to explore) and a decent variety of skills/level ups.You can complete levels without killing anyone or you can simply go rambo mode and kill everyone on your way, up to you.It's about 8 or 9 hours of gameplay, but it becomes a bit repetitive... it's always the same, hide behind something, distract, kill, whatever. But it is still an enjoyable game. It's definitely worth the price.7.5/10

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												Let me tell you a story. Spoilers, obviously.When I started playing this game, my approach was to "ghost" through the levels. "Ghosting" refers to passing through the level undetected without harming anyone, as though you were never there to begin with. I reasoned that, because my character was at risk of going mad, this path of restraint would be a logical choice for them.Then I got to a point where it was quite clear I would be unable to progress without one of two things happening: killing a guard, or being detected. Maybe once I beat the game and had more tools available I could come back and ghost the level, but with my current inventory it wasn't happening. So I killed them. I reasoned that, because killing undetected was worth far more points than not killing after being detected, this is how I was intended to play the game.So I killed only when necessary to avoid detection. Then I killed when doing otherwise would have been inconvenient. Then I killed when I felt like it. Eventually, and before I knew it, I was backtracking across the map to hunt down a single enemy that had escaped my wrath.Killing was no longer part of the game. Killing WAS the game. Each kill was an exercise in self-expression and creativity. Whatever the risk was for impending madness, I didn't care. I was having way too much fun.Then I reached the end of the game, and it was pointed out to me that I had indeed gone mad, that I was hallucinating, and that it was my duty to end my life. Now, whatever amount of killing I may have done, after terrorizing a enemy to shoot another enemy with their assault rifle, it seemed MORE likely that they had at least HELD an assault rifle than that I was merely imagining them doing so. Hallucinations don't inflict real bullet wounds on other hallucinations. What's more, whatever my disposition might have been, these people had still killed a friend of mine, and they had been trying to kill me.So I said, screw that. At the very least, you buggers will die first.And then the credits rolled, and the epilogue was revealed.They were right. I HAD become a monster. And now I had unleashed myself on the world. I was unseeable, I was untouchable, and I was unstoppable. I was a terror, I had been given the chance to end my life, and I didn't. And now there was no stopping me.That this was so perfectly conveyed through my gameplay experience is a greater compliment to the developers than any words can describe.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
NOTE: This review is somewhat bordering on an incredibly short essay (I am not comfortable with this, considering my disdain for writing them). Also, I did not bother to proof read it, so pardon any mistakes you find in it. Enjoy!In a nutshell, the game has splendid stealth mechanics. The level design is also great. I did not feel as if my approach to each encounter was the correct, and only way (as some puzzles are) -- instead I found it to be *my* way. The level design opens up a lot of different angles to tackle each part of the game. Though to some, at a first glance, it may seem like a puzzle, with only one correct way of solving it -- it is, in fact, quite unlike that idea. The encounters are challenging and do feel rewarding to accomplish.*Spoilers Follow (minor)* Besides the mechanics, the actual story was rather good. It seems rather straightforward but as you progress, the plot unfolds and reveals a larger, more complicated narrative than what was first provided. The game manages to explore eastern cultural traditions and values, and juxtaposes them with the thought and notions brought upon by western culture. Though the former is quite obvious and leads to the premise of the story, the latter is only really touched upon at the conclusion of the game. The contrasting cultural ideas (such as selflessness vs individualism) provided a provacative choice upon the game's conclusion, affecting the fate of not only your own, but of the people around you. It is not done in a simplistic bad vs good or black vs white choice, but rather it is based off the player's perception of what they believe is correct. Even still, the narrative poses a strong moral grey fork in the decision -- What you believe is correct may not be the best choice. Alternatively, the best choice may not be what is objectively correct.The game forgoes a notion of a "good", "happy" or even "correct" ending, and instead leaves it with the player to determine, in their own thoughts, whether their chosen fate was more justifiable than the other.At least for me, I find it rare for games to create any meaningful, thought provoking decisions, let alone explore themes and ideas that extend beyond superficiality and cliches. With that said, this game was thoroughly refreshing to have played, both in gameplay and in story.I refuse to provide a grade or score for this game, and often, I refuse to do it for many other things. I do not believe the value of the game can be easily quantified (at least by me). I will, instead, allow the words that precede this paragraph to describe the value. I do recommend this game, however everyone has their own tastes. This game requires patience, so keep that in mind if you are prospecting to purchase "Mark of the Ninja".

content:
Posted: July 19, 2013
												Mark of the Ninja is a challenging stealth game where your reflexes and puzzle-solving abilities will be tested in tandem. The level design is top-notch - at no point will the gamer feel like they are grinding their way through the game. Exploration is rewarded with various ninja tools which offer additional options for distracting or eliminating troublesome guards. What makes this game truly excellent however is the proportion of gameplay which relies on player skill and intelligence, rather than luck or powerups. Combine that with a fairly intriguing storyline, appropriate music, and immersive environments: it will become clear that Mark of the Ninja is a well-polished game which does precisely what it set out to do.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Story:Unfortunately, this was the most lacking thing for me in MotN. The plot itself was just not compelling and interesting enough. Although the presentation was suberb I thought a good  and engaging would have made this game so much better. The characters were cool but they could have had more depth. But it is by no means a bad story, it just had much more potential and the game as a whole didn't suffer too much, that's why I won't give the story a bad score.8/10Graphics:I liked this style a lot; It reminded me of old Cartoon Network cartoons, especially Samurai Jack. The cutscenes were well made and I liked how it worked with silhouettes and shadows. All in all it was very pleasant too look at and very stylish and clean. Note: For me there were no technical issues and the frame rate was always constant.8.5/10Sound:This game just has a few and mostly atmospheric tracks, which is the perfect fit for a stealth game. But still I wished more memorable tracks. The voicework is well done, but still could have been more proffesional. The sound effects are authentic and sets you in the mood.8/10Gameplay:This is stealth game through and through. You certainly don't want to get caught, so this game is nothing for Rambo-Style-Action fans. I had some difficulties with the controls at first but after some time I really got used to them. As a Ninja you are offered a variety of tools and paths to get through a levels, eg. Kunais, Spike Mines, Lethal or Non-Lethal etc. To unlock some new skills and tools you need Honor Points, those are earned by getting a certain amount of points, completing optional objectives and finding scrolls and artifacts. Every level is filled with traps, enemies and puzzles, so evry level has the same formula, but still I never felt it was repetitive. Every level felt different and interesting. They game is challenging and sometimes you are confronted with trial and error, so again, nothing for short-fused gamers. The game is kinda short, but as soon as I finished I wanted to 100% this game, so there is a high replayability.9/10Conclusion:(Again:This is nothing for action fans!)This is a pure stealth game and one of the best ones I've ever played. It is addictive, full of variety and ways to play and challenging. While the other categories are a bit lacking and there was potential for more this is just a must for every stealth fan! 88/100

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Coming into this game, I didn't have very high expectations - after all, stealth/action isn't really my genre. As I played it, however, I found that many elements of gameplay are quite satisfying. I feel that the game had good player direction, as I never felt that I was being led along, but I also never felt confused as to where I needed to go. The question I would often ask myself was not, "What am I supposed to do?" but rather, "How am I going to do it?". It's an incredibly fun experience being able to assess a situation, and recognize multiple ways of approaching the situation.The art and animation in the cutscenes is done exceptionally well, and for some reason I find myself thinking back on Samurai Jack whenever I see it. In-level art is also done in a way that keeps everything dark and fitting for the mood, but still clearly recognizable to the player through the use of silhouettes.All in all, I would say that this game is a good choice for those who like stealth action, and even for those who want to try something new and fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												I haven't played too much stealth games in the many year's of gaming but offhand I have to say that this is a pretty sweet deal. Those who are fans of classic side scroll games should get this one as it makes for a good break from all the usual mechanics of the platform. The shadowy business you get into in this games is presented quite well. The art style was the first thing that got me hooked - this game is the bloodier, darker, more violent cousin of Samurai Jack. Set in a modern day metropolis, the environment makes for a good contrast to the ancient arts of the ninja. The ancient ways will be challenged by all modern means - guns, spotlights, motion sensors, and laser triggered security.  The shadowy arts never felt any simpler with the smoothness of controls - there is little room for the awkward movements and bad camera angles in this 2D platformer. Slipping in and out of the shadows is one click away! This, I think, is another good score for the game as it leaves only your good timing and judgement to deal with a present challenge. Levels have varied goals to meet - the game can't be done perfectly by just staying hidden in the shadows forever. There are instances where your blade will get stained. (In some occasions, the goals aren't even related to being a ninja but it's all fun and challenging all the same.)As you progress into the game, your are introduced to its very own customization system. Clearing goals allow you to buy additional stealth kills and improved ninja styles and tools.The story - which I haven't finished, actually, isn't really that unique. Revenge and self-preservation is its very core to say the least, cloaked in shadow and with a very sharp sword. For those who are fans of side-scrolling and stealth, this one should definitely not be missed.

Guards, they're stupid, What I mean by is that, I jump down from a ledge and assassinate his buddy, doesn't even turn around, so to avenge his pal (did'nt even give a second glance at me killing his bro) I murdered the deaf guard, though that itself could be a pro, Deaf guards, Heh Heh Heh Heh Heh, MWHAHAHAHAHAHAH!!!2. LvL 1, It's Hard, rescuing ninjas and saving the sensei, though it's one of the most fun levels in the game (i'm only a bit into lvl 2 xD.Well thats all I can think of about this game, Please Forgive me if this review is'nt long enough, i've only put 81 mins into the game!So a basic overview on this whole entire game, ready?, STABBY STABBY STABBY STABBY STABBY STABBY STABBY STABBY STAB MCSTABBINGS!!!420/69 IGNBuy it! for 15 bucks it is one hell of a GREAT game, maybe even MLG, wait, yes it's MLG, in fact it's too MLG 4 ME OR 4 U!!!P.S: When I got this game, like a day ago, I thought the graphics looked like Disney and I thought it was made by Disney!!!Then I thought, Wait, Gore, Violence, Killing, Assassinations, Nope this is not Disney!!!This beautiful game that I'm writing a review for was made by the wonderful people at Klei Entertainment, who also made Don't Starve (Also hand drawn and original soundtrack!)Most Original Game Of the Century (2000-2099)Good Job Klei Entertainment, I just want to go up to you guys and give you guys A BIG WARM HUG!!!By Little Baby Man @GEWP

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												I was looking for a game that would give me a pretty good ninja experience and this one didn't disappoint. This is a cool side-scrolling stealth platformer where you get to unlock and use all kind of ninja tools to sneak by guards in each level, or dispatch them in any number of ways. The game has cool mechanics; you can climb walls, hang from the ceiling, run, sneak, traverse air ducts, knock out lights, terrify guards, kill them, distract them with noise makers, hide behind or in things, glide, and all kinds of other ninja-like things. You have to be careful not to be seen and you have to be careful of noises you make. All of these mechanics are well-implemented in a 2-D world. You can go completely pacifist if you want to; you'll just have to be extra sneaky as you traverse each level. There are puzzles that make sense as you navigate buildings and take out security systems. The story is just so-so and I wasn't crazy about the "Samurai Jack" cartoony style of look to the game, but the game is really fun to play. There is full controller support, but it was a little wonky at times; specifically when trying to aim some of your thrown weapons. Other than that, I recommend this game if you think ninjas are totally sweet.

I still do, to this day, but Mark of the Ninja is such an outstanding game that I cannot recommend it enough.Buy it right now. 18€ for one of the best games of this decade is a steal.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												A great stealth game with a decent amount of diversity, not thrown in all at once. Easy to learn, hard to master. Good replayability: has nice achievements, challenges for each level ("seals") and exploration for hidden stuff. If you're good at it, you'll be able to get upgrades faster. Upgrades are not like "in your way", but they are still very useful: new ways to kill, to move, to trick people.Classic stelath with light exposure and sound as your main foes. A great number of ways to handle just about anything with either lethal takedowns (in many ways!), clever distraction (like scaring the s**t out of people), or just avoidance ("don't mind me, just passin' through"). All spiced up with cartooney yet serious art style (Klei is good at it!) and good audio (music and SFX).Challenging if you want it to be: in New Game+ (unlocked after normal playthrough) things are pushed a bit towards realism: you can't see behind yourself, you can't visibly determine sound's detection range. Nothing forces you to try it though, there's not much to miss without it.Not without its drawbacks: since it's stealth, it's often dark in there. And some really crucial elements are sometimes difficult to detect. And controls are clunky when it comes to precision moves (even "focus" doesn't help much with that). When it doesn't though, they are great: responsive and mostly express your intentions fast.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2013
												Disclaimer: Might be a bit weird, it's late and I have no clue if what I write makes sense. :)Mark of the Ninja is a game you should buy.If you like sneaky games this is definitely for you. It’s one of the best ninja-sneaky-backstab games I have ever played and the sheer intelligence and commitment of the devteam to create a great experience for the player is admirable.It took me maybe 14-17 hours for my first playthrough (guessing), and the rest of the time (of a total 26,6h) to play the new DLC level, playing it through again in NG+ and collecting all achievements.In short it’s a platform sneak game, you play as a ninja with various skills, keeping to the shadows and trying to advance by backstabbing or avoiding the enemies. You are not the strongest fighter and while you can fight one-on-one, you won’t survive multiple alert enemies, so you take it slow and plan your way forward.However, if things go south you can always flee, or just reload, often you have a checkpoint just outside the area that you tried to clear, so you can be back where you was in a matter of seconds. The game load saves instantly, I have reloaded some checkpoints probably 10-15 times over and over just because I haven’t gotten the right outcome.So, the game is great, the areas present different challenges with both puzzles and enemy encounters, forcing you to become a better ninja.Gameplay and design is top-notch, they have put a lot of time in everything from how you make sound to how the enemies walk, act and react. You see enemy sightcones, if they have nightvision, what status they are in and when you run what soundwaves that you make, giving you optimal information to how to approach any situation.Through a time-stop mode you can queue up several actions that will be performed by the ninja. So while you are jumping off from a light you can stop time and throw two darts and a poisonbomb and then grapple away to a treebranch.You have optional suits to change up your gameplay, I enjoyed almost all of these in my NG+ playthrough, some giving you hilarious combos and chain effects that makes you squeal happily in your seat.NG+ makes the game harder by removing most of the help that you get as a player, after having played the normal mode and learning these things by heart, it’s very thrilling to not see what’s behind your character. Having to guesstimate how close you can run up to an enemy before he notice your footsteps, or how close you can get to the dog without it picking up your trail. Going by enemy design to judge if they have night-vision and if they are looking in your direction. I enjoyed NG+ maybe even more than normal mode, but the normal mode was excellent practice for it, if I hadn’t played the game in normal mode first, I probably wouldn’t have liked NG+.So, bad stuff, honestly it’s not that much. Controls can act up a bit, they can be kind of finicky where you need to look to get the correct action. When it’s a tight space and you slide down just behind an enemy you miss some actions that would seem natural to do.Some checkpoints in the later levels are horrendous, especially in the last level where you can spawn inside a house where there is a very dangerous enemy patrolling, whom you don’t want to get seen by. Some areas are very large, making a small mistake cost you a lot of work. But most of the time it just work and feels natural.I’ve probably become annoyed by more things but honestly they are a speck of dust on a gem.Graphics pretty much look like a very, very pretty flashgame, same with the cinematics. Don’t look down on this, it looks awesome and the ninja animations are awesome. A lot of work have gone into the style to make surfaces and the areas both pretty and functional.Music is mostly ambient, works well but nothing you will write love poems about.Technically it worked fine, I played with a Xbox 360 controller and had no crashes or anything mess my game up.Hope you buy it and enjoy it as much as I did! :D

												From the creators of the Shank series and Don't Starve comes this black pearl.I usually dont play stealth games. Brute Force is more my thing. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2013
												Easily one of the best Stealth games out there. Mark of the Ninja is one of the best games to come out in 2012. As a stealth game it's really well done, the idea that you're a ninja and not a samurai is a brilliant emphasis on the play style this game presents. As a Ninja your mission is to avenge your clan and take out the bad guys. Pretty simple in the story department. Gameplay is 2D and all the information you need to know is there, how much sound you make is given off by rings broadcasted from the last position you made noise, if enemies are with the radius of these rings then they'll investigate. The greatest thing is enemies suffer from fear, as you do horrible things to the unlucky schmucks they'll start panicking and this can go either way as they shoot their buddies or hit you in the process. Combat is pretty non-existent in this game. You can stun enemies, but you'll most likely be out-numbered and killed in that pursuit. Instead your attacks come in the form of gadgets, like traps. As long as an enemy cannot see you, you can kill in up-close stealth take-down form! The last point I want to make is masks. Masks alter the game in subtle ways that change how you approach sandboxes for example there is a mask that lets you take more Offensive gadgets or there is a mask that makes your enemies panic if they see corpses of their buddies anywhere (not just hanging from lamp-posts). The masks are all unlockable and this ties in with the game's replayability. The game is already highly replayable but the masks add different flavours of fun, and that's something the game is, amazing fun!
